content: Product Development Roles: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Product Development Roles//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Governance Product Development Roles The roles described in the vets.gov product methodology are defined below. These roles are specific to new product development for vets.gov and/or existing VA website / product / content migration activities and are aligned with the detailed phases described in the methodology. Vets.gov Team: Project Delivery Project and product management Clearly define project goals, scope, roles, and milestones at project kickoff Manage project activities, and migration process to vets.gov Define vets.gov aPlaybooka with standards, product development methodology, and requirements to migrate to vets.gov Veteran user research and human centered design expertise Lead user testing activities and manage veteran testing group Aggregate and analyze user data collected in VE activities in a format that can inform design and functionality improvements Content Concurrence Manage the content concurrence process Provide content writing, editorial, and plain language expertise and guidance Work collaboratively with VA team members to complete content concurrence per the Sept. 3 memo. Design, develop, and deploy Migrate existing VA websites and services Work collaboratively with other vendors who may be providing design and/or development services on vets.gov projects Develop new services based on veteran needs Ongoing operations, maintenance, and improvements Operations and maintenance (O&M) Review and analyze vets.gov feedback VA Business Owner: Business Owner / Product Owner Work with vets.gov team to lead the team in defining project goals, scope, roles, and priorities at project kickoff Approve project charter Make decisions and help manage product activities in collaboration with vets.gov team Approve / accept product VA Product Lead: Project Coordinator Serve as the primary point of contact for the vets.gov team Work with vets.gov team to coordinate kickoff meeting and assists with discovery activities Coordinate the collection of business requirements Provide technical requirements to vets.gov team Coordinate team meetings (conference room, schedules, etc.) Respond to vets.gov questions in a timely manner Assist with development of project schedule Manage approved project schedule activities Manage third party vendors for vets.gov project activities (if relevant) Ensure third party vendors meet requirements and standards in Vets.gov Playbook. VA Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) Provide business requirements. Provide details about VA services. Provide end user (Veteran) data and feedback. VA Web Content Writers Participate in the vets.gov content concurrence process as required. Review content for factual errors. Other VA Vendors (Designers, Developers) Adhere to vets.gov Playbook requirements, standards and guidelines Perform activities as defined in the project schedule Work collaboratively with vets.gov team members and VA team members on the project Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Is there a way to file that can get me a decision faster?: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Is there a way to file that can get me a decision faster?//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsApply for BenefitsIs there a way to file that can get me a decision faster? Apply for Disability Benefits Fully Developed Claim The Fully Developed Claims (FDC) program is an optional way for Veterans and survivors to get faster decisions by submitting all relevant records in their possession, and those records which are easily obtainable, such as private medical records, when they make their claim and certify that they have no further evidence to submit. VA can process these claims more quickly. Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs) To speed up the processing of compensation and pension claims, you now have the option of completing an examination with your own healthcare provider instead of at a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) facility. If you choose to go to your own healthcare provider, you will need to bring the appropriate Disability Benefits Questionnaires, or DBQs. These downloadable forms that are specific to your condition or symptom enable private healthcare providers to capture important information needed by VA to accurately evaluate and promptly decide on your claims for benefits. Visit our DBQ List by Form Name or DBQ List by Symptom to access the 70 forms available. See detailed instructions: Veteran VSO Health Care Provider Where can I get more information? See our DBQ Frequently Asked Questions for more information. You can also call us at 1-800-827-1000 or ask us a question online. DBQs help support VAas Fully Developed Claims (FDC) program. DBQs are valuable for claims processing because they provide medical information that is relevant to determining a disability rating. When submitted with a Fully Developed Claim, DBQs ensure VAas rating specialists have precisely the information they need to start processing the claim. If youare an active-duty Servicemember, you can initiate a predischarge claim. What are the different ways I can file a claim? How do I get help filing a claim? How do I file while on active duty? How do I file for disabilities that appear within one year after discharge? Effective date of disability Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. content: C-123 Aircraft: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: C-123 Aircraft//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent OrangeC-123 Aircraft Apply for Disability Benefits Contaminated C-123 AircraftDates: 1969-1986C-123 Aircraft were used to spray Agent Orange during the Vietnam War. However, after being contaminated with chemical residue, they continued to fly throughout the world and did so through 1986. If you flew on or worked with these planes in Vietnam, or other locations, you may have been exposed. Are you eligible for disability compensation? Active-Duty Servicemembers Yes, if: You have an Agent Orangearelated disease. You served in a regular Air Force unit location where a contaminated C-123 was assigned. You regularly and repeatedly had contact with contaminated C-123 aircraft through flight, ground, or medical duties. This list of military units and Air Force Specialty codes will help you figure out if your unit was exposed. Reservists Yes, if: You have an Agent Orangearelated disease. You were assigned to flight, ground, or medical crew duties at any of the following locations: Lockbourne/Rickenbacker Air Force Base in Ohio, 1969-1986 (906th and 907th Tactical Air Groups or 355th and 356th Tactical Airlift Squadrons) Westover Air Force Base in Massachusetts, 1972-1982 (731st Tactical Air Squadron and 74th Aeromedical Evacuation Squadron, or 901st Organizational Maintenance Squadron) Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania International Airport, 1972-1982 (758th Airlift Squadron) This list of military units, Air Force specialty codes, and dates of service will help you figure out if your unit was exposed. How to Apply for Benefits Online This is the fastest way to file a claim and receive your decision: Go to eBenefits Select a Disability Benefit After you select a disability in your eBenefits form, make sure you type C-123 next to the disability in the text box. If you have any of the following material, upload it with your online application: Discharge, separation papers (DD214 or equivalent) USAF Form 2096 (unit where assigned at the time of the training action) USAF Form 5 (aircraft flight duties) USAF Form 781 (aircraft maintenance duties) Dependency records (marriage certificate and children's birth certificates) Medical evidence (doctor and hospital reports) How to Apply for Benefits by Mail or Fax File by mail by printing out and filling in this form: VA Form 21-526EZ Make sure you include each C-123-related disability in Section I, Block 11A on the form, and submit copies of any of the material noted aboveaif you have itawith your paper claim. Discharge or separation papers (DD214 or equivalent) USAF Form 2096 (unit where assigned at the time of the training action) USAF Form 5 (aircraft flight duties) USAF Form 781 (aircraft maintenance duties) Dependency records (marriage certificate and childrenas birth certificates) Medical evidence (doctor and hospital reports)Mail claims to:Department of Veterans Affairs Claims Intake CenterAttention: C123 ClaimsPO Box 5088Janesville, WI53547-5088Fax claims to:608-373-6694QuestionsC-123 Hotline:1-800-749-8387 St. Paul Regional Benefit Office:VSCC123.VAVBASPL@va.gov Fact Sheet:C-123 aircraft and Agent Orange exposure Find an accredited Representative to help you. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Employers:Log in to create/manage your account. Sign in with LinkedIn Sign in with Google Post a Job Your listing will be searchable by our capable Veteran workforce and their families. Find Veteran Candidates Leadership, problem solving, management, operations, customer service, sales, and a host of technical skills are just a few of their talents. View their profiles and save favorites. Make a Hiring Commitment Stand with Veterans by making a public commitment to hire Veterans. Your pledge will be appreciated by all Americans, and especially by the Veteran community. Related Info: Workplace Support Find out how you can support Veterans and Sevicemembers in the workplace. On-the-Job Training Both on-the-job training (OJT) and apprenticeship programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r). Resources for Employers On-the-job training information, fact sheets, guides, and additional resources for employers. content: Appeals: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Appeals//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsAppeals Apply for Disability Benefits All benefits decisions can be appealed. If you disagree with all or part of a VA benefits decision, you may file a Notice of Disagreement (NOD). Veterans Service Organizations can assist you with this. When do I file an NOD? Youall need to file within one year from the date on the letter notifying you about the decision on your claim. What do I file? File VA Form 21-0958. Whatas next? Your local VA office will prepare and mail to you a written explanation, known as the Statement of the Case (SOC), which explains why your claim was denied. You may submit additional evidence, or request that VA obtain certain evidence for you, after you receive your Statement of the Case. Your local VA office will review your new evidence and send you a Supplemental Statement of the Case. What if I still donat agree? If you disagree with the Statement of the Case, you can file a Substantive Appeal to the Board of Veteransa Appeals. When do I file a Substantive Appeal? Youall need to file within one year from the date on the letter notifying you about the original decision on your claim or 60 days from the date on the letter accompanying the Statement of the Case, whichever gives you more time. What do I file? File VA Form 9. Check the status of your appeal by calling 1-800-827-1000 or going online to eBenefits. How the Board of Appeals works: If you selected an optional in-person or video teleconference hearing with a Veterans Law Judge at the Board of Veteransa Appeals, the hearing will be scheduled at your local VA office (or in Washington, DC, if you selected that location). You may request an optional personal hearing before an adjudicator who works at your local VA office or a Veterans Law Judge who works at the Board of Veteransa Appeals. If you request an optional hearing, it will significantly delay a Board decision because optional hearings take more time to schedule. The Veterans Law Judge will make a decision on each issue of your appeal. The decision will grant, remand, or deny each issue. Grant: If an issue is granted, your local VA office will notify you of the decision made by the Board of Veteransa Appeals. Remand: If an issue is remanded, it means that one or more issues in your appeal will be sent back to a local VA office for further evidence collection. Your appeal will return to the Board of Veteransa Appeals when the local VA office complies with the Boardas remand instructions. Deny: If an issue is denied, and you want to pursue further action, you may: File a new claim with your local VA office, File a motion asking the Board of Veteransa Appeals to reconsider your appeal (there is no time limit to file this motion), File a motion asking the Board of Veteransa Appeals to review your appeal again because there was clear and obvious error in its decision (there is no time limit to file this motion), and/or File a Notice of Appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. When? Youall need to file within 120 days from the date of the decision by the Board of Veteransa Appeals (stamped on the first page of the decision). What do I file? File a Notice of Appeal. Send your Notice of Appeal to the Clerk of the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Follow these detailed instructions. Learn more: How Do I Appeal? pamphlet Board of Veterans' Appeals Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. Veterans Employment Center For Employers Commitments Employers every day are committing to hire Veterans -- you should too! Check out the list below to see what employers have already made a commitment and then create or update your profile to signal your commitment. Of the 14638 registered employers with the Veteran Employment Center(tm): 1439 public commitments made 815973 total positions committed to hire 425048 Veterans hired so far Download all commitments as spreadsheet Employers:Log in to create/manage your hiring commitment. Sign in with LinkedIn Sign in with Google Commitments Company Committed to hire By date Hired so far Walmart Logisticshttp://walmartcareerswithamission.com/who-you-are/transitioning-veterans/ Looking for: various Special commitments to: Veteran Spouse 100000 2018-05-31 40000 Walmart DC 7019 Brundidge, Alabama Looking for: Area Managers for our shipping and receiving department and Operation Managers Special commitments to: Veteran 100000 2018-05-31 67000 Home DepotArizona Looking for: Lot, Cashier,Sales, Freight, Recieving Special commitments to: Veteran Homeless Spouse 65000 2016-12-31 250 Uber Technologies, Inc. https://newsroom.uber.com/2014/09/ubermilitary-we-want-you/ Looking for: Uber Driver Partners Special commitments to: Veteran Homeless Spouse 50000 2016-01-01 41000 Blackstone Headquarters in New York; Porfolio companies across the country Looking for: Positions across our diverse group of portfolio of companies, which include: Hilton, La Quinta, Michaels Stores, GCA, Pinnacle Foods Corporation, Vivint and others. 50000 2019-01-01 10000 UPSAtlanta, GA Looking for: Part time package handlers, delivery drivers, CDL drivers, IT positions, automotive mechanics, Inside Sales Representatives and Finance and Accounting positions Special commitments to: Veteran 50000 2018-12-31 34000 FASTPORT - Hiring Our Heroes Trucking Track Looking for: Trucking Industry Special commitments to: Veteran Spouse 50000 AlliedBarton Security Services120 Offices Nationwide Looking for: Security Officers, Supervisors, Dispatchers Special commitments to: Veteran 25000 2018-04-01 15700 Enterprise HoldingsNationwide Looking for: Sales Management Trainee, IT, Accounting, Automotive Tech/Mechanic, various Customer Service Support roles Special commitments to: Veteran 10000 2020-12-31 2000 Comcast/NBC Universal National Looking for: We offer thousands of different roles at Comcast/NBC Universal from Installation Technician to Sales, Customer service to field operational roles. There are many opportunities! Special commitments to: Veteran Spouse 10000 2017-12-31 2000 Related Info: Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Components//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Design Components Components Vets.gov components are page level design elements that help visitors navigate, scan, and understand information. For further guidance visit the U.S. Web design standards. Navigation Vets.gov is launching with a mobile friendly lightweight navigation system. Breadcrumbs Breadcrumb links appear in the header of each content page to help visitor navigate and keep track of their location. Card Navigation Card style navigation is used on topic landing pages to indicate major content areas. List Navigation List navigation links to tertiary and quaternary pages. Quick Links Quick links are used to callout key content or actions for easy access. Footer The footer provides site navigation and key external links. Page Elements Callout Box Callout boxes are used to highlight important content areas and make pages easier to scan. Definition Block Definition blocks help users to quickly identify information that is relevant to them and provide links to more detailed information. Lists Lists can used to decrease content density and organize information. They can be ordered or unordered. Process List The process is an ordered list variation and helps to parse complex tasks into step-by-step instructions. Veterans Employment CenterFor Job Seekers Military Skills Translator Enter your military position {{state.error}} Branch of Service Military Occupation Code (MOC) Scroll down for results {{data.mo.moc != 'DEFAULT' ? data.mo.moc : ""}} {{data.mo.moc && data.mo.moc != "DEFAULT" ? ":" : ""}} {{data.mo.title ? data.mo.title : "(Unknown MOC)"}} {{data.mo.service}}, {{data.mo.category}} You can also skip directly to the Resume Builder Translate your military experience into language that private sector employers understand. Selecting Skills: Employers look for specific capabilities that you've demonstrated in your past roles. Consider selecting skills that are tangible and are relevant to jobs that interest you. You can also add skills not on the list. After selecting skills: Use the button at the bottom to automatically import them into the Resume Builder. The skills translator is based on a new big data partnership with LinkedIn. The more Veterans who use the tool, the better the suggestions will become over time. Thoughtfully finding your own skills will help future Veteran users get even better results. Click Skills to select them Add {{skill.name}} Suggest more skills.. content: Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillUndergraduate and Graduate Degrees If you would like to earn an advanced degree at an institution of higher learning, including four-year universities, community colleges, and schools offering advanced degrees, VA education and training benefits may be available to you. The number of classes you attend and the accompanying hours spent in those classes determine your payments. For example, for most undergraduate degrees, a college considers: 12 or more hours full time 9-11 hours three-quarter time 6-8 hours half time Less than six hours as reimbursable at a rate thatas no more than the tuition and fees charged for the course(s) If you are interested in graduate-level training, the school determines how each hour is rated. For example, if a two-hour class is considered full time in a graduate program at your school, VA will pay you the full-time rate. You can attend more than one college at a time under the GI Bill as long as the classes at both institutions count toward your degree, and the school granting your degree accepts the classes at the second school as part of your requirements. However, the GI Bill will not pay you to take the same class twice, unless you receive a failing grade in a class that is a graduation requirement. The GI Bill can pay you for the classes required to achieve more than one degree. Once you earn a degree, you could pursue another one if you have remaining entitlement on your GI Bill. VA issues payments after each monthas classes. For example, you receive the November payment in December. For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the tuition and fees are paid directly to the school, the book stipend is paid to you at the beginning of the term, and the housing allowance is paid to you at the end of each month. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Care should be taken to communicate these changes to users and to help them transition as needed. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Rates//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsRates Apply for Disability Benefits How VA Calculates Compensation Rates The amount of compensation depends on the severity of your disability. VA determines this based on the evidence you send us, as well as the information VA obtains about your disability. VA rates disability from 0% to 100% in 10% increments (for example, 10%, 20%, 30%). See the Combined Ratings page for information about how VA calculates disability percentage for multiple disabilities. You may be paid additional amounts, in certain instances, if: You have very severe disabilities or loss of limb(s). You have a spouse, child(ren), or dependent parent(s). You have a seriously disabled spouse. content: Editorial Guide: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Editorial Guide//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> PlaybookEditorial GuideEditorial GuideEditorial Principles and Style Language communicates our humanity.A In the context of a website, it conjures up the people on the other side of that glowing screen. It engages, builds trust, and guides visitors through processes and information that can be stressful and confusing.The primary headline on our home page reflects that: How can we help?Vets.govas language is clear and direct, yet its tone is warm and quiet. We respect Veteransa time, so we get to the point. And we avoid bureaucratese.We donat say utilize when use works just as well.We avoid saying manifested, because started says it better.We distill and simplify. Weare not selling programs and benefits, but rather helping Veterans and their families understand whether a benefit is right for them so they can make informed choices about how to proceed. Our goal is to give Veterans and their families the information they need to make important decisions confidently, easilyaand done.Additional ResourcesThe Veterans Benefit Administration Style Guide (PDF)The Veterans Health Administration Style Guide (PDF)The Chicago Manual of Style Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Resume Builder Already have a profile saved on vets.gov? Sign in to access it. Build a Profile & Resume Use this form to create a public profile so employers committed to hiring Veterans can find you here on the Veterans Employment Center(tm). Manually enter your information into the form fields below, or use the Auto-fill from LinkedIn button to pre-populate some of the fields from your LinkedIn account. (Not all fields will be populated). Auto-fill from LinkedIn LinkedIn is also providing a free 1-year Job Seeker Premium subscription ($360 value) to all U.S. Veterans and Servicemembers. Learn more here. (This section is required for Federal job applications) Add the basics Enter your name Your Name Your Email Required State Your Objectives Enter basic information about your career goals and objectives. 1 - 2 sentences about your qualifications and career objectives. This appears in search results, so make it stand out! (This section is required for Federal job applications) When can you start work? When can you start work? Available (estimate) as of (MM/DD/YYYY) Your Civilian Skills Add your civilian skills. Add as many as necessary by using the autocomplete field Add a new skill (press enter to add): + Add Another Skill (This section is required for Federal job applications) Education & Training Add your education information. Add as many as necessary by using the add education experience link. Name of school or training Type of credential earned Please select oneSome High School CourseworkHigh School or equivalentTechnical or Occupational CertificateAssociate's DegreeSome College Coursework CompletedBachelor's DegreeMaster's DegreeDoctorateProfessional Credential topic Description Start date (MM/DD/YYYY) End date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if you are still completing this education) + Add Education Experience Military Service Add your military information. Add as many as necessary by using the add military experience link below. Military Occupation Code Duty Station Branch of Service Rank Please select your rankE-1E-2E-3E-4E-5E-6E-7E-8E-9W-1W-2W-3W-4W-5O-1O-2O-3O-4O-5O-6O-7O-8O-9O-10 Title Describe Your Position Responsibilities Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Military Experience Work Experience Add your employment information. Add as many as necessary by using the Add work experience link below. (This section is required for Federal job applications) Position Organization Describe Your Position Responsibilities Hours/Week Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Work Experience Volunteer Experience Add your work experience. Add as many as necessary by using the Add volunteer experience link. Position Organization Description Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Volunteer Experience Awards Enter your award information. Add as many as necessary by using the Add award link. Name of Award Awarding Organization Date Received (MM/DD/YYYY) + Add Award Professional Affiliations Enter your job title information Affiliation Affiliated Organization + Add Affiliation (This section is required for Federal job applications) References Add your professional references. Add as many as necessary by using the add reference link. Name Email Title + Add Reference Location Preference Enter your location preferences below. Add as many as necessary by using the Add another location link. (For the best employment search results, specify one or more cities rather than just a state or country.) Desired Location + Add Location Other Enter optional additional information to assist potential employers in finding your profile. Indicate any special categories that apply to you: Caretaker Family Member Guard/Reservist Smooth Takeoff Project Junior Military Officer (O1-O4) Service-Connected Disabled Veteran Service-Connected Disabled Veteran (10%) Service-Connected Disabled Veteran (30%) Transitioning Servicemember Military Spouse Veteran Save As Draft Let employers find and view your profile, or save it as a draft. Check this box if you DON'T want employers to find and view your profile. Save as draft Your profile will only be visible to employers after you log in to save your information. Some may not be apparent until years after you have completed your service.A disability can apply to physical conditions, such as chronic knee pain, as well as mental-health conditions, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).ConditionsWhat conditions qualify me for benefits?RatesHow does VA calculate compensation rates?Claims processHow does the claims process work?AppealsWhat if I disagree with my rating decision?Apply for Benefits Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: What is Quick Start?: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: What is Quick Start?//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPredischargeWhat is Quick Start? Apply for Disability Benefits If you are in predischarge status between 1 and 59 days before separation, retirement, or release from active duty or demobilization, Quick Start allows you to submit a claim for disability compensation. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You have a known separation date. Your separation date is 1 to 59 days away. You are full-time Active Duty, National Guard, or Reserves. Who is covered You Available benefits Expedited status decision on your disability claim How it works By submitting your disability compensation claim before discharge, you can receive VA disability benefits as soon as possible after separation, retirement, or demobilization. You must submit your service-treatment records to VA when you submit your claim, and you must complete all phases of the VA/DOD medical separation examination process at your point of separation and before you are released from the military. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Discover: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Discover//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Product Methodology Discover Step 3: Discovery Discovery validates and expands upon the initial project definition. Deeper understanding is developed through design research focused on business and customer needs. Technical investigation also happens in this phase. These activities serve as the foundation for product concept exploration. Outputs Discovery Report i Leads Project Team POC Project Team Leads VA Product Lead Participants Engineering Full stack engineer Site reliability engineer Front-end developer Engineering lead Data scientist Content Strategist VA Product Lead VA Content Writers VA SMEs Design researcher UX Designer VA Stakeholder Engagement Participate in working sessions to provide business requirements, validate design concepts, and provide feedback to vets.gov team as needed. Provide requested documentation and timely responses to questions as requested. Provide introductions / access to end users as available. Provide any available feedback or data about end users Develop launch communication plan Provide input for sunset strategy for systems and content Engineering Identify all required data elements. Identify data collection needs and data-driven goals. (For example, tracking completion rates for a form, or top search terms.) Identify related systems. Plan for rebuild, or integration. (For example, sending an electronic disability claim.) Define system architecture including data, security, integrations and services Search Identify current user search terms on Google, VA.gov Identify initial keyword list Content Define goals for content. What do users need? Review existing content, online and off. What can be incorporated? What needs to be newly created? Define feature set a the content elements that will be included in this release. Use Vets.gov Style Guide in creating new content and revising any thatas reused. Design Research Review existing research to determine how much additional research is required. Create a research plan Conduct research Synthesize findings Document findings Share with larger core vets.gov team and with the business partner team Design Heuristic audit Back: Kickoff Next: Alpha: Design, Prototype & Plana" Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. Veterans Employment Center(tm) The Veterans Employment Center(tm) connects Veterans and their families with meaningful employment and career development opportunities. Resources and tools for both job seekers and employers. Job Seekers Map your military skills, build a civilian resume, and post your profile so employers will easily find you. Search our career opportunities, and learn about organizations that can assist you with career development and employment. Employers Access Veterans who are seeking employment directly by searching verified profiles of Veterans and their spouses. Post open positions. Make a public hiring commitment. Access Veteran experience and skills and hire the best! Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Hazardous Exposures//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous Exposures Apply for Disability Benefits You may be eligible for disability compensation if you were exposed to certain chemical, physical, and environmental hazards during military service that resulted in disease or injury. Agent Orange The U.S. military sprayed millions of gallons of Agent Orange and other herbicides on trees and vegetation during the Vietnam War. Several decades later, concerns about the health effects from these chemicals continue. Asbestos Service activities and jobs that may have health consequences Birth Defects Contaminated Drinking Water at Camp Lejeune Chemicals in the camp's water from1953 to 1988 now pose health risks. Gulf War Illness The many diseases associated with serving in Southwest Asia Ionizing Radiation Exposure risks include nuclear testing, having been a POW in Japan, working with x-rays or at a reactor, and more. Mustard Gas Field or chamber testing, WWI battlefields, German bombing of Bari, Italy during WWII, and more. Project112/SHAD Chemical testing exposure --1962 to 1974 and survivor benefits. Radiogenic Risk Activities WWII-era service or imprisonment in Japan, nuclear weapons testing, gaseous diffusion plant assignment, and more. Specific Environmental Hazards Exposure problems in Iraq, Afghanistan, Dijibouti, Camp Lejune, NC, and Atsugi, Japan, from burn pits and particulate matter to chemically contaminated drinking water. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. We're designing in the open. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.gov GI Bill(r) Benefits Comparison Tool Learn about education programs and compare estimated benefits by school EXPLOREYOUR CAREER CareerScope COMPARESCHOOLS GI BillComparison Tool CHOOSEA SCHOOL Decision Guide APPLY FORGI BILL VONAPP SUCCEEDIN SCHOOL EducationalCounseling FINDEMPLOYMENT Employment Center Step 1: Tell Us About Yourself About You: Military Status: Veteran Active Duty National Guard / Reserves Spouse Child Is your spouse on active duty? Spouse Active Duty Spouse Not Active Duty Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? Post-9/11 GI Bill (Ch 33) Montgomery GI Bill (Ch 30) Select Reserve GI Bill (Ch 1606) REAP GI Bill (Ch 1607) Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E) Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) Cumulative Post 9-11 Active Duty Service: 36+ months: 100% (includes BASIC) 30 months: 90% (includes BASIC) 24 months: 80% (includes BASIC) 18 months: 70% (excludes BASIC) 12 months: 60% (excludes BASIC) 6 months: 50% (excludes BASIC) 90 days: 40% (excludes BASIC) Less than 90 days 0% (excludes BASIC) GYSGT Fry Scholarship: 100% Service-Connected Discharge: 100% Completed an enlistment of: 3 or more years 2 or more years Length of Longest Active Duty Tour: 2+ years of consecutive service: 80% 1+ year of consecutive service: 60% 90+ days of consecutive service: 40% To apply for VR&E benefits, please visit this site. Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Not Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Number of Dependents 0 Dependents 1 Dependent 2 Dependents 3 Dependents 4 Dependents 5 Dependents Military Status Post 9/11 GI Bill recipients serving on Active Duty (or transferee spouses of a servicemember on active duty) are not eligible to receive a monthly housing allowance. Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? You may be eligible for several types of VA education and training benefits depending on when and how long you served. There are several things to consider before you apply for a GI Bill program. One person may benefit more by using the Montgomery GI Bill while another may make an irrevocable election and use the Post-9/11 GI Bill instead. This tool allows you to compare the different programs and make an educated decision on which benefit best suits your needs. For more detailed information on eligibility requirements and general program benefits, please check out this page. Cumulative Post-9/11 Service The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides financial support for education and a housing allowance to qualifying individuals with at least 90 days of aggregate service after September 10, 2001, or individuals discharged with a service-connected disability after 30 days. You must have received an honorable discharge to be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill.For more detailed information Cumulative Post-9/11 Service, please check out this page. Completed an enlistment of (MGIB): The Montgomery GI Bill - Active Duty provides education benefits to Veterans and Servicemembers who have served at least two years of active duty. When using this tool, you will need to select the length of your original active duty enlistment obligation in order to get an estimate of your monthly benefit. The amount of time you served (2 year enlistment vs. 3+ year enlistment) will impact your monthly payment amount when using the Montgomery GI Bill. To learn more about MGIB please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/mgib_ad.asp Length of Longest Active Duty Tour (REAP) The REAP program pays benefits to eligible Reservists or Guard members who were called or ordered to active duty for at least 90 consecutive days in response to a war or national emergency declared by the President or Congress. REAP payment amounts are based on length of consecutive days of active duty service with rates increasing at one year and again at two years of consecutive service. To learn more about REAP please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/reap.asp. $(document).ready(function() { ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Military Status select show and hide ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#military-status').change(function() { showDependent('#military-status', 'spouse', '#spouse-active-duty-form', 100); }).change(); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // GI Bill benefit select ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#gi-bill-chapter').change(function() { var opt = $(this).val(); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '33', '#cumulative-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '30', '#enlistment-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '1607', '#consecutive-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#voc-rehab-warning', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#elig-for-post-gi-bill-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#number-of-dependents-form', 100); }).change(); $('.filter-item').change(function() { runEstimator(); }).change();});// Makes the modals work!$("a[rel*=leanModal]").leanModal(); Use the VA's GI Bill Comparison Tool to make the most of your GI Bill Benefit. Whether you want to apply your GI Bill benefits to college classes or an on-the-job training program, this tool will help you make the most of them. $ Tuition & Fees $ Housing $ Books What's Your Plan? Transitioning to civilian life takes preparation, research, planning, and the right tools. We're here to help you make the right decisions on where to use your hard earned benefits! Step 2: About Your School Will you be taking classes online? All No Both Enter a city, school or employer name: $(document).ready(function() { $('#institution-search').val(""); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Institution autocomplete ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#institution-search').autocomplete({ minLength : 3, source: "/gi-bill-comparison-tool/institutions/autocomplete.json", select: function(event, ui) { event.preventDefault(); $("#institution-search").val(ui.item.value); $('#input-section').submit(); }, }); $('#institution-search').keypress(function(e) { if ((e.keyCode == 13 || e.which == 13) && !$(this).val()) { e.preventDefault(); } }); $("#search-button").click(function(e) { if (!$('#institution-search').val()) { e.preventDefault(); } });}); Post 9/11 GI Bill Approved Programs You can use the Post-9/11 GI Bill at colleges, universities, trade schools, and for on-the-job training, apprenticeship, and flight schools. To see what programs are currently approved for VA benefits, go to our website. You can use the Post 9/11 GI Bill for tutorial assistance, licensing/certification tests (attorney license, cosmetology license, etc.) and national exams (SAT, LSAT, etc.). The Post 9/11 GI Bill Comparison Tool uses a list of schools offering approved programs from VA's database. The GI Bill Comparison Tool will update its list of approved programs quarterly. However, new information is added to the VA database every day. content: Principles of Excellence Program: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Principles of Excellence Program//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsCareer CounselingPrinciples of Excellence Program The Principles of Excellence program requires participating educational institutions to: Provide a personalized form to help you understand the total cost of your educational program, including: Costs covered by your benefits. Financial aid you may qualify for. Your estimated student-loan debt upon graduation. Other information to help you compare aid packages offered by different schools. Provide an educational plan with a completion timeline that shows how and when you can fulfill the requirements for graduation. Designate a point of contact to provide you with ongoing academic and financial advice (including access to disability counseling). Accommodate both long and short absences due to service obligations for active-duty Servicemembers and Reservists. Ensure accreditation of all new programs before enrolling students. Align their refund policies with those under Title IV, which governs the administration of federal student financial aid programs. End fraudulent and aggressive recruiting techniques and misrepresentations. Institutions that do not charge tuition and fees are not required to comply with the Principles of Excellence. This includes: Foreign schools High schools On-the-job training and apprenticeship programs Residency and internship programs Use the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool to maximize your educational benefits and learn which schools participate. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Predischarge: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Predischarge//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPredischarge Predischarge It is to your benefit to start the process of filing a disability claim while you are on active duty in predischarge status. Processing times tend to be faster for claims submitted before separation than for those submitted after separation. If you are in predischarge status, you may file a claim for disability compensation up to 180 days prior to separation or retirement from active duty or release from full-time Reserve or National Guard periods of duty. If you are between 60 and 180 days from separation, you can begin the Benefit Delivery at Discharge (BDD) program. Between 1 and 59 days before separation, you can initiate the Quick Start Claim. See also Benefit Delivery at Discharge (BDD) program Quick Start program Overseas Intake Sites Disability Compensation Rates Other programs available to predischarge Servicemembers Standard Claim Original Claim Reopened Claim New Claim Secondary Claim Fully Developed Claim (FDC) Preservice Claim In-Service Claim Predischarge Claim Postservice Claim Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. content: Standard Claim: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Standard Claim//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesStandard Claim If you file a standard claim, VA will gather evidence from public and private medical facilities so they can process your disability claim. VA will gather evidence from private medical facilities only with your authorization. Who can file a standard claim? You, your dependents and survivors Why use the standard claim process? If you want VA to assist you in gathering evidence to support your claim, you should file a standard claim. With your approval, VA will gather needed evidence, listed in your claim, including information not held by federal agencies. This may include medical records from: private medical providers private doctorsa offices state and local governments current or former employers Evidence Requirements Medical evidence of a current physical or mental disability, and Evidence of an event, injury, or disease while you were in service Note: A standard claim will generally take longer to process than a Fully Developed Claim. content: Legacy Programs: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Legacy Programs//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsLegacy Programs Before the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r), several smaller programs provided education benefits to Servicemembers and Veterans. Veteran Service Officers and the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool can help you pick the right program for your goals. Reserve Educational Assistance Program (REAP) Activated Reservists qualify for additional education benefits. National Call to Service An education benefit earned with a mix of military and civilian service. Veterans' Educational Assistance Program (VEAP) A government match program for educational assistance. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Kickoff//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Product Methodology Kickoff Step 2: Kickoff The kickoff meeting is conducted after completion of project definition and brings together the entire project team. It creates alignment and shared understanding of the projectas goals, scope, milestones, roles and responsibilities. It builds on the project definition phase by eliciting known business requirements, user needs and technical platform dependencies. Output Kickoff meeting i Draft Project Plan i Leads Project Team POC VA Business Owner VA Product Lead Participants VA kickoff attendees identified by VA Business Owner Project Team POC Design Team Engineering Team VA Business SMEs VA Technical SMEs (as needed) VA Stakeholder Engagement Ensure the right people attend the kickoff meeting given the agenda Work collaboratively with the vets.gov team to prepare for the kickoff Team Assemble entire team. (Invite subject matter experts, when relevant.) Review project goals, timeline and definitions. Adjust as needed. Develop sprint cycle plan Review known business requirements. Review known user needs Review known technical and platform dependencies Identify constraints and risks Back: Project Definition Next: Discovery Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Licensing and Certification: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Licensing and Certification//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsTraining, Testing, or LicensingLicensing and Certification If you are a Veteran looking for employment in a field that requires a license or certification, you may be eligible for VA GI BillA(r) reimbursement for licensing or certification exams. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You are eligible for the GI BillA(r) You are taking an exam that costs less than $2,000 Who is covered You Available benefits Reimbursement under the GI BillA(r) How it works VA may reimburse you for tests necessary for you to become a licensed or certified mechanic, medical technician, attorney, therapist, website developer, computer network engineer, or other professional. After you submit proof of payment, VA will reimburse you. There is no limit to the number of tests you may take, or the number of times you take the same test. VA pays for tests even when you donat score high enough to achieve your license or certification. Find out how your GI BillA(r) entitlement will be charged for using a licensing and certification benefit. Fees associated with obtaining a license or certification are not reimbursable. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Preservice Claim//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPreservice Claim Claims Based on Preservice Disabilities If you entered the military with a known disability that became worse or was aggravated due to your service, you may be eligible for benefits. In these cases, disability compensation is calculated based on the level of aggravation. For example, if you had a condition that was 10% disabling when you entered the military and it worsened due to service to 20% disabling, then the level of aggravation would be 10%. content: Apply for Education Benefits: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Apply for Education Benefits//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsApply for Education Benefits Who Should Read This Servicemembers and Veterans seeking education and training opportunities How long does a decision take? The time it takes to process your claim depends on your regional office. There are four regional claims processing centers, and it varies region by region. You can use VAas interactive map to find out how quickly your regional office processes claims. What are the steps? Research Learn about schools offering VA-approved programs by using the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool. Decide which school is best for you. Please note that it is not required, but it is an option, to apply to a chosen school prior to applying for benefits. Gather Your Documents The following documents will help VA process your claim: DD214 (Member 4), discharge or separation papers, for all periods of active-duty service, excluding active duty for training DD2384, Notice of Basic Eligibility (NOBE), which you can get through your Reserve unit Orders, if activated from the Guard or the Reserves Apply You have four options for filing your claim: Apply online using eBenefits. Go to a VA regional office and have a VA employee assist you. Work with your schoolas VA certifying official. This person is usually in the Registrar or Financial Aid office at the school of your choice. Call 888-GI Bill (888-442-4551) to have the application mailed to you. After you complete it, mail it to your VA regional claims processing office. VA Review You can track the status of your application on eBenefits. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. We're designing in the open. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.gov GI Bill(r) Benefits Comparison Tool Learn about education programs and compare estimated benefits by school EXPLOREYOUR CAREER CareerScope COMPARESCHOOLS GI BillComparison Tool CHOOSEA SCHOOL Decision Guide APPLY FORGI BILL VONAPP SUCCEEDIN SCHOOL EducationalCounseling FINDEMPLOYMENT Employment Center Step 1: Tell Us About Yourself About You: Military Status: Veteran Active Duty National Guard / Reserves Spouse Child Is your spouse on active duty? Spouse Active Duty Spouse Not Active Duty Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? Post-9/11 GI Bill (Ch 33) Montgomery GI Bill (Ch 30) Select Reserve GI Bill (Ch 1606) REAP GI Bill (Ch 1607) Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E) Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) Cumulative Post 9-11 Active Duty Service: 36+ months: 100% (includes BASIC) 30 months: 90% (includes BASIC) 24 months: 80% (includes BASIC) 18 months: 70% (excludes BASIC) 12 months: 60% (excludes BASIC) 6 months: 50% (excludes BASIC) 90 days: 40% (excludes BASIC) Less than 90 days 0% (excludes BASIC) GYSGT Fry Scholarship: 100% Service-Connected Discharge: 100% Completed an enlistment of: 3 or more years 2 or more years Length of Longest Active Duty Tour: 2+ years of consecutive service: 80% 1+ year of consecutive service: 60% 90+ days of consecutive service: 40% To apply for VR&E benefits, please visit this site. Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Not Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Number of Dependents 0 Dependents 1 Dependent 2 Dependents 3 Dependents 4 Dependents 5 Dependents Military Status Post 9/11 GI Bill recipients serving on Active Duty (or transferee spouses of a servicemember on active duty) are not eligible to receive a monthly housing allowance. Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? You may be eligible for several types of VA education and training benefits depending on when and how long you served. There are several things to consider before you apply for a GI Bill program. One person may benefit more by using the Montgomery GI Bill while another may make an irrevocable election and use the Post-9/11 GI Bill instead. This tool allows you to compare the different programs and make an educated decision on which benefit best suits your needs. For more detailed information on eligibility requirements and general program benefits, please check out this page. Cumulative Post-9/11 Service The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides financial support for education and a housing allowance to qualifying individuals with at least 90 days of aggregate service after September 10, 2001, or individuals discharged with a service-connected disability after 30 days. You must have received an honorable discharge to be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill.For more detailed information Cumulative Post-9/11 Service, please check out this page. Completed an enlistment of (MGIB): The Montgomery GI Bill - Active Duty provides education benefits to Veterans and Servicemembers who have served at least two years of active duty. When using this tool, you will need to select the length of your original active duty enlistment obligation in order to get an estimate of your monthly benefit. The amount of time you served (2 year enlistment vs. 3+ year enlistment) will impact your monthly payment amount when using the Montgomery GI Bill. To learn more about MGIB please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/mgib_ad.asp Length of Longest Active Duty Tour (REAP) The REAP program pays benefits to eligible Reservists or Guard members who were called or ordered to active duty for at least 90 consecutive days in response to a war or national emergency declared by the President or Congress. REAP payment amounts are based on length of consecutive days of active duty service with rates increasing at one year and again at two years of consecutive service. To learn more about REAP please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/reap.asp. $(document).ready(function() { ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Military Status select show and hide ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#military-status').change(function() { showDependent('#military-status', 'spouse', '#spouse-active-duty-form', 100); }).change(); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // GI Bill benefit select ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#gi-bill-chapter').change(function() { var opt = $(this).val(); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '33', '#cumulative-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '30', '#enlistment-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '1607', '#consecutive-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#voc-rehab-warning', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#elig-for-post-gi-bill-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#number-of-dependents-form', 100); }).change(); $('.filter-item').change(function() { runEstimator(); }).change();});// Makes the modals work!$("a[rel*=leanModal]").leanModal(); Use the VA's GI Bill Comparison Tool to make the most of your GI Bill Benefit. Whether you want to apply your GI Bill benefits to college classes or an on-the-job training program, this tool will help you make the most of them. $ Tuition & Fees $ Housing $ Books What's Your Plan? Transitioning to civilian life takes preparation, research, planning, and the right tools. We're here to help you make the right decisions on where to use your hard earned benefits! Step 2: About Your School Will you be taking classes online? All No Both Enter a city, school or employer name: $(document).ready(function() { $('#institution-search').val(""); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Institution autocomplete ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#institution-search').autocomplete({ minLength : 3, source: "/gi-bill-comparison-tool/institutions/autocomplete.json", select: function(event, ui) { event.preventDefault(); $("#institution-search").val(ui.item.value); $('#input-section').submit(); }, }); $('#institution-search').keypress(function(e) { if ((e.keyCode == 13 || e.which == 13) && !$(this).val()) { e.preventDefault(); } }); $("#search-button").click(function(e) { if (!$('#institution-search').val()) { e.preventDefault(); } });}); Post 9/11 GI Bill Approved Programs You can use the Post-9/11 GI Bill at colleges, universities, trade schools, and for on-the-job training, apprenticeship, and flight schools. To see what programs are currently approved for VA benefits, go to our website. You can use the Post 9/11 GI Bill for tutorial assistance, licensing/certification tests (attorney license, cosmetology license, etc.) and national exams (SAT, LSAT, etc.). The Post 9/11 GI Bill Comparison Tool uses a list of schools offering approved programs from VA's database. The GI Bill Comparison Tool will update its list of approved programs quarterly. However, new information is added to the VA database every day. content: Reopened Claim: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Reopened Claim//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims processClaim typesReopened Claim You can file a reopened claim for a benefit that VA previously denied if a year has passed since your claim was denied and you did not appeal that decision. However, VA cannot reopen a claim without new and material evidence. aNew evidencea is information about the claimed benefit that the VA has not previously considered. aMaterial evidencea is information that is relevant to and has direct bearing on the specific claimed benefit. Example:A Veteran was treated several times during service for pain in his right elbow. He filed a claim for service connection, but his claim wasnat granted because when the Veteran was examined the VA doctor didnat find a problem. Two years later, the Veteranas elbow was x-rayed by his private physician. His doctor found arthritis. The Veteran applied to reopen his VA claim, sending in his private doctoras exam results a new and material evidence. Because the recent exam suggested his current elbow pain was an after-effect of his in-service elbow problems, VA reopened his claim. content: Secondary Claim: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Secondary Claim//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesSecondary Claim It is possible for your service-connected disability to cause, or to worsen, another disability. If this is the case, you can file a secondary disability claim to seek additional benefits. This second disability may not otherwise be considered service connected. Example 1 A Veteran has a service-connected knee injury that causes him to walk with a limp. He subsequently develops arthritis in his hip. The arthritic condition did not start during service, nor was it aggravated by service, but service connection may still be established if the arthritis is a result of his previously established service-connected knee condition. Example 2 A Veteran was in the Army for twenty years. During her military service, she was diagnosed with hypertension. After her discharge, service connection was established for hypertension. She was subsequently diagnosed with a coronary artery disease that resulted from her hypertension. She may file a secondary claim to establish service connection for her coronary artery disease. content: What is a "presumed disability"?: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: What is a "presumed disability"?//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessWhat is a "presumed disability"? A presumed disability is a diagnosed disability that VA considers to be related to a Veteranas service because of the circumstances of the Veteranas military service. This designation usually applies to conditions that are the result of a specific hazardous exposure or a chronic disease that appears within one year after discharge. content: National Call to Service Program: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: National Call to Service Program//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsLegacy ProgramsNational Call to Service Program If you performed a period of national service, you may be eligible for the National Call to Service program, which allows you to choose an education benefit as an alternative to the Montgomery GI BillA(r). Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You completed your initial entry training, and then continued to serve on active duty in a military occupational specialty designated by the Secretary of Defense for a period of 15 months. You then, without a break in service, served either an additional period of active duty as determined by the Secretary of Defense or a period of 24 months in active status in the Selected Reserve. You then, without a break in service, spent the remainder of your obligated service as follows: On active duty in the Armed Forces, or In the Selected Reserve, or In the Individual Ready Reserve, or In AmeriCorps, or another domestic national service program jointly designated by the Secretary of Defense. Who is covered You Available benefits You may select from the following: A cash bonus of $5,000. Repayment of a qualifying student loan not to exceed $18,000. Educational assistance equal to the three-year monthly Montgomery GI BillA(r) Active Duty rate for 12 months. Educational assistance equal to 50% of the less-than-three-year monthly Montgomery GI BillA(r) Active Duty rate for 36 months. How it works If you enlist under the National Call to Service program, you are not eligible for the MGIB, unless you reenlist at a later date for an additional period of service. Contact your recruiter to discuss your eligibility and to enroll in the National Call to Service program. This benefit affects your service contract. Learn more Read the National Call to Service program pamphlet. This program is administered by VA for the Department of Defense. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Education and Career Counseling: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Education and Career Counseling//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsCareer CounselingEducation and Career Counseling If you are transitioning out of active service soon, you are entitled to free educational and career counseling services. Are you eligible for services? Yes, if: You will be discharged from active duty within six months. You were discharged from active duty not more than one year ago. You qualify for educational assistance under Chapters 30, 31, 32, 33, 35, 1606, and 1607. You and your qualified dependents are eligible for and have entitlement to education assistance under the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r). Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Academic and career counseling How it works As a transitioning Servicemember, you are eligible to receive the following services: Counseling to help you decide which civilian or military occupations to pursue. Educational and career counseling to help you find a training program or job. Academic and adjustment counseling to help resolve issues that interfere with your success in training or employment. Apply for free counseling services. Use CareerScopeA(r), the VA aptitude assessment tool, at no cost. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Agent Orange: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Agent Orange//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent Orange Apply for Disability Benefits The U.S. military sprayed millions of gallons of Agent Orange on trees and vegetation during the Vietnam War. Several decades later, concerns about the health effects from these chemicals continue. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You were exposed to Agent Orange during military service. Who is covered You or your dependents How it works These diseases are a result of exposure to Agent Orange. VA forgoes the normal requirement that you prove an illness began during or became worse because of your military service. If you have a disease that is not on this list but you believe it is a result of Agent Orange exposure, you will need to prove your illness began during or became worse because of your military service. See also Agent Orange Registry Health Exam for Veterans Non-Hodgkinas Lymphoma and Agent Orange Were you exposed? content: GI Bill: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: GI Bill//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI Bill What is the GI Bill? Since 1944, millions of Veterans have used the GI Bill to pay for college. The GI Bill is designed to help Veterans successfully transition from military to civilian life through educational attainment. The Post-9/11 GI Bill gives Veterans with active-duty service on or after September 11, 2001, enhanced educational benefits that cover more educational expenses and provide a living allowance, money for books, and the ability to transfer unused educational benefits to spouses or children. This benefit has changed over time, and you currently have several options to choose from. Veterans Service Organizations and the GI Bill Comparison Tool can help you pick the right benefit program for your goals. Foreign Programs Institutions of Higher Learning Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees Post-9/11 GI BIll Transfer Your Post-9/11 GI Bill Benefits to Your Spouse and Dependents Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) Montgomery GI Bill Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR) Survivors' and Dependents' Assistance Rates Yellow Ribbon Program Tuition Assistance Top-Up $600 Buy-Up Program Tutorial Assistance Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary.
