Veterans Employment Center For Employers Resources On the Job TrainingBoth on-the-job training (OJT) and apprenticeship programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r). These programs allow Veterans to learn a trade or skill through training on the job participation rather than attending formal classroom instruction.A Veteran generally enters into a training contract for a specific period with an employer or union, and at the end of the training period, the Veteran gains job certification or journeyman status.Employers participtating in an OJT program are able to hire a Veteran at the apprenticeship wage and have the salary supplemented by VA. The training often results in permanenet full-time employment and provides employers with a well-trained Veteran employee.Veteran Employment Fact Sheets & Reference GuidesFind Your Nearest American Job Center (AJC)America's Heroes At Work provides FAQs, dispels myths, provides information on workplace accommodations, and offers promising practices for employment success. The site also provides information on hiring Veterans with disabilities, including disability employment laws and legal issues, tax benefits and other financial incentives related to Veterans with Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI).VA for VetsAs a supervisor or HR professional, you make a difference every day for the Veterans or Military Servicemembers on your staff. VA for Vets offers services that help you to recruit Veteran talent to the civilian workforce, ensure they acclimate to the culture and have the resources they need to continue their military service.Additional Resource CollectionsFind a Local VR&E CoordinatorThe VR&E program provides services to eligible Veterans with service-connected disabilities prepare for, obtain and maintain suitable employment. Services include career exploration, training and education, and employment services. A Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment Coordinator can help you in hiring service connected disabled veterans. Follow the link above to find your local VR&E office.Toolkit for Veteran Friendly InstitutionsDesigned to help institutions of higher education build effective programs for Veteran students and share information.Department of Labor resources:Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment PolicyResources for EmployersVeterans' Employment and Training Services (VETS)Office of Federal Contract Compliance ProgramsCompliance Assistance - Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)A Toolkit for Federal Agencies on Implementing Executive Order 13548 Related Info: Workplace Support Some ways to support Veterans and Sevicemembers in the workplace. On the Job Training Both on-the-job training (OJT) and apprenticeship programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r) Vets.gov Benefits Disability Benefits Education & Training Resources Veterans Employment Center(tm) Facility Locator GI Bill(r) Comparison Tool Process Playbook Blog Connect Facebook Twitter VA | U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs VA.gov Accessibility Privacy USA.gov Veterans Crisis Line 1-800-273-8255 (Press 1) Help Us Create vets.gov: A Message from Secretary Robert McDonald We need your feedback to make Vets.gov better. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Job Resources Assistive Technology The Assistive Technology Act of 2004 defines an assistive technology device as "...any item, piece of equipment, or product system, whether acquired commercially, modified, or customized, that is used to increase, maintain, or improve functional capabilities of individuals with disabilities." See also: Assistive Technology Act of 2004 National Assistive Technology Technical Assistance Partnership This website provides a contact list, by state, of providers of assistive technology. Information included in most state information is the address, contact person, telephone number, and email address. A website with more information about services and resources may also be accessed. See also: National Assistive Technology Technical Assistance Partnership Directory of Independent Living Centers This website provides a listing, by state, of all independent living centers. Generally, contact information and the area of jurisdiction for each center is also provided. See also: Directory of Independent Living Centers AbleData This website is maintained for the National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research (NIDRR) of the U.S. Department of Education. Selecting Products on the home screen begins a search of items that are classified in 20 areas, such as Aids for Daily Living, Blind and Low Vision, Communication, Housekeeping, Seating, and may others. Searches may also be initiated by typing specific information in the search box. See also: AbleData Center for Assistive Technology and Environment Access This website was created with funding from NIDRR and the Rehabilitation Services Administration and contains over 22,000 products. Basic searches may be performed by Function, Activity, or Vendor. To help make the search process more specific, there are drop-down selections in a wide range of areas. The site also allows users to compare products. See also: Center for Assistive Technology and Environment Access (CATEA) - National Public Website on Assistive Technology Homemods.org This website is a project of the National Resource Center on Supportive Housing and Home Modification. It promotes independent living as well as aging in place for all individuals. In addition to Resources and a Directory, selecting FAQs will enable users to access a checklist that to assess safety concerns in the home. See also: Homemods.org Technology for Long-Term Care This website focuses on providing information about technology products that can be used for individuals in long-term care settings. However, the information on the site can also be used by persons living at home with disabilities. Products are organized into 13 basic categories, but users may also browse by company. See also: Technology for Long-Term Care Related Info: Are you a Veteran job seeker? Visit the Job Seeker Section to search jobs, translate your skills, and build a resume. Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Predischarge//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPredischarge Predischarge It is to your benefit to start the process of filing a disability claim while you are on active duty in predischarge status. Processing times tend to be faster for claims submitted before separation than for those submitted after separation. If you are in predischarge status, you may file a claim for disability compensation up to 180 days prior to separation or retirement from active duty or release from full-time Reserve or National Guard periods of duty. If you are between 60 and 180 days from separation, you can begin the Benefit Delivery at Discharge (BDD) program. Between 1 and 59 days before separation, you can initiate the Quick Start Claim. See also Benefit Delivery at Discharge (BDD) program Quick Start program Overseas Intake Sites Disability Compensation Rates Other programs available to predischarge Servicemembers Standard Claim Original Claim Reopened Claim New Claim Secondary Claim Fully Developed Claim (FDC) Preservice Claim In-Service Claim Predischarge Claim Postservice Claim Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: CareerScope//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsCareer CounselingCareerScope In addition to career counseling, VA provides the interest and aptitude assessment tool, CareerScope, to all eligible benefit recipients. CareerScope has been used frequently by Veterans to determine the best career path when transitioning to civilian life. CareerScope uses the results from your assessment to give you recommendations that help identify which career fields you may enjoy and in which careers you might excel. CareerScope also recommends courses or training programs that can help you pursue those careers. Use this Report Interpretation guide to help you understand your CareerScope results. content: Yellow Ribbon Program: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Yellow Ribbon Program//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillA(r)Yellow Ribbon Program If your school participates in the Yellow Ribbon Program, you may be able to reduce or eliminate your education costs that are not covered by the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r), such as higher tuition at private colleges or out-of-state schools. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You are a Veteran or the dependent of a Veteran who is eligible for transfer of entitlement for the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r), or you are the child of an active-duty Servicemember who is the recipient of a transfer of entitlement. You are eligible to receive 100% Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) benefits. Is this me? Your school participates in the Yellow Ribbon Program for the 2015-16 school year. You maintain continuous enrollment, full- or part-time, as defined by your school. You are working toward the completion of your enrolled program. Who is covered You and your family members Available benefits Additional tuition How it works After you submit your application for Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) benefits and VA finds you eligible, you will receive a Certificate of Eligibility. Bring this certificate to your participating institutionas financial aid, military liaison, or other office as determined by your school, and ask to apply to your schoolas Yellow Ribbon Program. Your school will determine: Whether it has already enrolled the maximum number of participants for the program period. Enrollment is on a first-come, first-served basis. Your school and VA agree on how many students may be covered each year. What the amount of entitlement will be. This is calculated by adding up tuition and mandatory fees, and then subtracting any specific aid youave received from other sources such as scholarships or grants as well as your Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) tuition payment. Your school applies the Yellow Ribbon Program benefit to this final amount. You will receive notice from your school about whether you have been accepted to the program and about the application of the benefit to your tuition. Confirm that your school will submit your enrollment information to VA, and coordinate with VA for the application of the benefit to your tuition or fees. Learn more FAQs about the Yellow Ribbon Program Yellow Ribbon Program pamphlet Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. content: Automobile Use Claims: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Automobile Use Claims//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsAutomobile Use Claims Apply for Disability Benefits If you have a service-connected disability that prevents you from driving an automobile or other conveyance, you may be eligible for a one-time payment of $20,114.34 toward buying a specially outfitted vehicle. You may also qualify for more than one adaptive-equipment grant to modify a vehicle with power steering, brakes, seats, windows, or lift equipment to assist you with getting into and out of the vehicle. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: Your service-connected disability includes at least one of the following conditions: Loss, or permanent loss of use, of one or both feet. Loss, or permanent loss of use, of one or both hands. Permanent impairment of vision in both eyes: Central Visual acuity of 20/200 or less in the better eye with glasses, or Central Visual acuity that is greater than 20/200, accompanied by a visual field defect in which your peripheral field has contracted to such an extent that the widest diameter of visual fields subtends an angular distance no greater than 20 degrees in the better eye. Severe burn injury. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Ankylosis (immobility of the joint) in one or both knees or hips (adaptive equipment grant only). Who is covered Veterans and Servicemembers Available benefits Compensation How it works In the case of these allowances, you must gain VA approval before purchasing an automobile or adaptive equipment. For the adaptive-equipment grant, the compensation may be paid to you or to the seller. For the one-time vehicle purchase grant, the compensation must be paid directly to the seller. You may request and receive either grant before or after military discharge. You must show that your disability is service connected or is treated as if service connected under 38 U.S.C. 1151. You will need to complete VA Form 21-4502 (Application for Automobile or Other Conveyance and Adaptive Equipment). If you are entitled to adaptive equipment only (for example, you have a service-connected disability due to ankylosis of the knees or hips), you should complete VA Form 10-1394 (Application for Adaptive EquipmentaMotor Vehicle). Special VA disability compensation programs include individual unemployability, automobile allowance, clothing allowance, prestabilization, hospitalization, convalescence, dentistry, and birth defects. If you are a Veteran with a service-connected disability rating, you may be eligible for special compensation to help with the following: Automobile Use ClaimsBirth Defects/Spina BifidaClothing AllowanceConvalescenceDentistryHospitalizationIndividual UnemployabilityTitle 38 U.S.C. 1151Prestabilization Ratings Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Fry Scholarship: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Fry Scholarship//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillA(r)Survivors' and Dependents' AssistanceFry Scholarship The Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship (Fry Scholarship) provides Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) benefits to the children and surviving spouses of Servicemembers who died in the line of duty while on active duty after September 10, 2001. If you qualify, you may receive up to 36 months of benefits at the 100% level. Full in-state tuition costs are covered at public institutions; up to $21,084.89 per year will be paid for training at private institutions. Are you eligible for Fry Scholarship benefits? Yes, if: You are the child or surviving spouse of an active-duty Servicemember who died in the line of duty on or after September 11, 2001. Who is covered Dependents and survivors Available benefits Fry Scholarship (GI BillA(r) benefits) How it works Children are eligible as of their 18th birthday or after graduating high school, whichever comes first. Childrensa eligibility ends on their 33rd birthday. A spouse has 15 years from the Servicememberas death to use the benefit. If you are a dependent and your parent died in the line of duty before August 1, 2011, you may be eligible for both the Fry Scholarship and the Survivorsa and Dependentsa Educational Assistance (DEA) program, but you can use only one program at a time. Combined benefits are capped at 81 months of full-time training. Surviving spouses are eligible to receive Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) while using the Fry Scholarship. Children over 18 who receive DIC benefits will need to give up those payments when they start to use the Fry Scholarship. Exception: Upon remarriage, a spouse will lose eligibility for this benefit. Apply Use the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool to help you choose a school. Make sure that your selected program is approved for VA training. Fill out VA Form 22-5490 (Dependentsa Application for VA Education Benefits). Send it to the VA regional office that has jurisdiction over the state where you will advance your education and training. If you are a son or daughter under legal age, a parent or guardian must sign the application. When applying, you will be required to make an irrevocable election of either the Fry Scholarship or the Survivorsa and Dependentsa Educational Assistance program. If you have already started your educational program, ask a certifying official from your school or your employer to request VA Form 22-1999 (Enrollment Certification) from their VA representative, complete it, and submit it online using VA-ONCE. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Montgomery GI BillA(r) Active Duty (MGIB-AD): Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Montgomery GI BillA(r) Active Duty (MGIB-AD)//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillA(r)Montgomery GI BillA(r) Active Duty (MGIB-AD) If you served at least two years on active duty, you may be eligible for the MGIB-AD program. Are you eligible for educational benefits? Yes, if: You were honorably discharged. You have a high school diploma, GED, or 12 hours of college credit. You meet the requirements of one of the categories below: CATEGORY I You entered active duty for the first time after June 30, 1985. You had military pay reduced by $100 a month for the first 12 months of service. You continuously served for three years, or two years if that was your enlistment agreement. Or if you entered the Selected Reserve within a year of leaving active duty, you continuously served for four years (the 2 by 4 program). CATEGORY II You entered active duty before January 1, 1977. You served at least one day between October 19, 1984, and June 30, 1985, and you stayed on active duty through June 30, 1988 (or through June 30, 1987, if you entered the Selected Reserve within one year of leaving active duty and served four years). On December 31, 1989, you had entitlement left from the Vietnam Era GI BillA(r). CATEGORY III You are not eligible for MGIB under categories I or II. You were on active duty on September 30, 1990, and you separated involuntarily after February 2, 1991. Or you involuntarily separated on or after November 30, 1993. Or you voluntarily separated under either the Voluntary Separation Incentive (VSI) program or the Special Separation Benefit (SSB) program. Before separation, you had military pay reduced by $1,200. CATEGORY IV You were on active duty on October 9, 1996, had money remaining in a VEAP account on that date, and elected MGIB before October 9, 1997. Or you entered full-time National Guard duty under title 32, USC, between July 1, 1985, and November 28, 1989, and you elected MGIB between October 9, 1996, and July 9, 1997. You had military pay reduced by $100 a month for 12 months or made a $1,200 lump-sum contribution. Who is covered You Available benefits School tuition or training fees How it works You may receive benefits for up to eight semesters (four years) of traditional academic education. The benefits, paid monthly, depend upon the following factors: length of service type of training your category (as defined below) college-fund eligibility your contribution to the $600 Buy-Up program Several related funding or training programs fall under the MGIB-AD umbrella: $600 Buy-Up program: While on active duty, you can contribute a maximum of $600 to receive increased monthly benefits. With this maximum contribution, you are eligible for up to an additional $5,400 in GI BillA(r) benefits. College degree and certificate programs Non-college degree programs (technical or vocational courses) Flight training Apprenticeships or on-the-job training High-tech training Licensing and certification Entrepreneurship training National testing program Correspondence training Use the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool to pick the right type of educational assistance program and school to maximize your benefits. aGI BillA(r) is a registered trademark of the United States Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). The absence of the registration symbol A(r) does not constitute a waiver of VAas trademark rights in that phrase.a Read our Terms of Use. Read the Montgomery GI BillA(r) Active Duty pamphlet. content: Product Development Roles: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Product Development Roles//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Governance Product Development Roles The roles described in the vets.gov product methodology are defined below. These roles are specific to new product development for vets.gov and/or existing VA website / product / content migration activities and are aligned with the detailed phases described in the methodology. Vets.gov Team: Project Delivery Project and product management Clearly define project goals, scope, roles, and milestones at project kickoff Manage project activities, and migration process to vets.gov Define vets.gov aPlaybooka with standards, product development methodology, and requirements to migrate to vets.gov Veteran user research and human centered design expertise Lead user testing activities and manage veteran testing group Aggregate and analyze user data collected in VE activities in a format that can inform design and functionality improvements Content Concurrence Manage the content concurrence process Provide content writing, editorial, and plain language expertise and guidance Work collaboratively with VA team members to complete content concurrence per the Sept. 3 memo. Design, develop, and deploy Migrate existing VA websites and services Work collaboratively with other vendors who may be providing design and/or development services on vets.gov projects Develop new services based on veteran needs Ongoing operations, maintenance, and improvements Operations and maintenance (O&M) Review and analyze vets.gov feedback VA Business Owner: Business Owner / Product Owner Work with vets.gov team to lead the team in defining project goals, scope, roles, and priorities at project kickoff Approve project charter Make decisions and help manage product activities in collaboration with vets.gov team Approve / accept product VA Product Lead: Project Coordinator Serve as the primary point of contact for the vets.gov team Work with vets.gov team to coordinate kickoff meeting and assists with discovery activities Coordinate the collection of business requirements Provide technical requirements to vets.gov team Coordinate team meetings (conference room, schedules, etc.) Respond to vets.gov questions in a timely manner Assist with development of project schedule Manage approved project schedule activities Manage third party vendors for vets.gov project activities (if relevant) Ensure third party vendors meet requirements and standards in Vets.gov Playbook. VA Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) Provide business requirements. Provide details about VA services. Provide end user (Veteran) data and feedback. VA Web Content Writers Participate in the vets.gov content concurrence process as required. Review content for factual errors. Other VA Vendors (Designers, Developers) Adhere to vets.gov Playbook requirements, standards and guidelines Perform activities as defined in the project schedule Work collaboratively with vets.gov team members and VA team members on the project Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Work Study: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Work Study//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsWork and LearnWork Study If you are a full-time or three-quarter-time college, vocational, or professional student using VA education benefits, you may be eligible for the work-study program. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You are enrolled at least three-quarter time at an institution of higher learning. You are using one of the following VA education benefits: Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) (Veterans and transfer-of-entitlement recipients) Montgomery GI BillA(r) (Active Duty and Selected Reserve) Reserve Educational Assistance Program Veteransa Educational Assistance Program Dependentsa Educational Assistance program (Note: Eligible dependents under 38 U.S.C. Chapter 35 may use work study only while enrolled at an educational institution in one of the 50 states.) National Call to Service Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program You are able to complete the work-study contract before the end of your eligibility for education benefits. There is a position available within your normal commuting distance. Who is eligible You and your dependents using education benefits Available benefits A part-time job while you study How it works The number of applicants selected will depend on the availability of VA-related work at your school or at VA facilities in your area. Veterans with service-connected disabilities of at least 30% may be given priority consideration. Learn more Download a copy of the Application for Work-Study Allowance. Contact the Regional Processing Office that handles your claim. Services you perform under a VA work-study program must be related to VA work, such as: Working at a VA facility. Working at Department of Defense, Coast Guard, or National Guard facilities engaged in the administration of the Montgomery GI BillA(r) Selected Reserve or the Reserve Educational Assistance Program. Working at a state Veterans agency to help Veterans obtain Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment benefits. Working at a Center of Excellence for Veteran Student Success to support and coordinate the academic, financial, physical, and social needs of Veteran students. Working in a cooperative program carried out jointly by VA and an institution of higher learning. Working in any Veterans-related position in an institution of higher learning, such as providing assistance to Veteran students with general inquiries about Veteran benefits, processing necessary documents, or maintaining and organizing Veteran-related files. How much will I earn? Youall earn an hourly wage equal to the federal minimum wage or your state minimum wage, whichever is greater. If youare in a work-study job at a college or university, your school may pay you the difference between the amount VA pays and the amount the school normally pays other work-study students doing the same job. You may elect to be paid in advance for 40% of the number of hours in your work-study agreement, or for 50 hours, whichever is fewer. After youave completed the hours covered by your first payment, VA will pay you each time you complete 50 hours of service, or biweekly, whichever comes first. You may work during or between periods of enrollment. The total number of hours you work during your enrollment canat be more than 25 times the number of weeks in your enrollment period. content: C-123 Aircraft: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: C-123 Aircraft//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent OrangeC-123 Aircraft Apply for Disability Benefits Contaminated C-123 AircraftDates: 1969-1986C-123 Aircraft were used to spray Agent Orange during the Vietnam War. However, after being contaminated with chemical residue, they continued to fly throughout the world and did so through 1986. If you flew on or worked with these planes in Vietnam, or other locations, you may have been exposed. Are you eligible for disability compensation? Active-Duty Servicemembers Yes, if: You have an Agent Orangearelated disease. You served in a regular Air Force unit location where a contaminated C-123 was assigned. You regularly and repeatedly had contact with contaminated C-123 aircraft through flight, ground, or medical duties. This list of military units and Air Force Specialty codes will help you figure out if your unit was exposed. Reservists Yes, if: You have an Agent Orangearelated disease. You were assigned to flight, ground, or medical crew duties at any of the following locations: Lockbourne/Rickenbacker Air Force Base in Ohio, 1969-1986 (906th and 907th Tactical Air Groups or 355th and 356th Tactical Airlift Squadrons) Westover Air Force Base in Massachusetts, 1972-1982 (731st Tactical Air Squadron and 74th Aeromedical Evacuation Squadron, or 901st Organizational Maintenance Squadron) Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania International Airport, 1972-1982 (758th Airlift Squadron) This list of military units, Air Force specialty codes, and dates of service will help you figure out if your unit was exposed. How to Apply for Benefits Online This is the fastest way to file a claim and receive your decision: Go to eBenefits Select a Disability Benefit After you select a disability in your eBenefits form, make sure you type C-123 next to the disability in the text box. If you have any of the following material, upload it with your online application: Discharge, separation papers (DD214 or equivalent) USAF Form 2096 (unit where assigned at the time of the training action) USAF Form 5 (aircraft flight duties) USAF Form 781 (aircraft maintenance duties) Dependency records (marriage certificate and children's birth certificates) Medical evidence (doctor and hospital reports) How to Apply for Benefits by Mail or Fax File by mail by printing out and filling in this form: VA Form 21-526EZ Make sure you include each C-123-related disability in Section I, Block 11A on the form, and submit copies of any of the material noted aboveaif you have itawith your paper claim. Discharge or separation papers (DD214 or equivalent) USAF Form 2096 (unit where assigned at the time of the training action) USAF Form 5 (aircraft flight duties) USAF Form 781 (aircraft maintenance duties) Dependency records (marriage certificate and childrenas birth certificates) Medical evidence (doctor and hospital reports)Mail claims to:Department of Veterans Affairs Claims Intake CenterAttention: C123 ClaimsPO Box 5088Janesville, WI53547-5088Fax claims to:608-373-6694QuestionsC-123 Hotline:1-800-749-8387 St. Paul Regional Benefit Office:VSCC123.VAVBASPL@va.gov Fact Sheet:C-123 aircraft and Agent Orange exposure Find an accredited Representative to help you. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.gov Search Close Search: Search: Content starts here. Veterans Employment Center Employers Find the best candidates for your open positions. Search our verified Veteran profiles. Post a job. And be sure to make a Veteran hiring commitment -- put your company front and center as one that stands with America's Veterans and their families. Employers:Log in to create/manage your account. Sign in with LinkedIn Sign in with Google Post a Job Your listing will be searchable by our capable Veteran workforce and their families. Find Veteran Candidates Leadership, problem solving, management, operations, customer service, sales, and a host of technical skills are just a few of their talents. View their profiles and save favorites. Make a Hiring Commitment Stand with Veterans by making a public commitment to hire Veterans. Your pledge will be appreciated by all Americans, and especially by the Veteran community. Related Info: Workplace Support Find out how you can support Veterans and Sevicemembers in the workplace. On-the-Job Training Both on-the-job training (OJT) and apprenticeship programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r). Resources for Employers On-the-job training information, fact sheets, guides, and additional resources for employers. content: Appeals: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Appeals//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsAppeals Apply for Disability Benefits All benefits decisions can be appealed. If you disagree with all or part of a VA benefits decision, you may file a Notice of Disagreement (NOD). Veterans Service Organizations can assist you with this. When do I file an NOD? Youall need to file within one year from the date on the letter notifying you about the decision on your claim. What do I file? File VA Form 21-0958. Whatas next? Your local VA office will prepare and mail to you a written explanation, known as the Statement of the Case (SOC), which explains why your claim was denied. You may submit additional evidence, or request that VA obtain certain evidence for you, after you receive your Statement of the Case. Your local VA office will review your new evidence and send you a Supplemental Statement of the Case. What if I still donat agree? If you disagree with the Statement of the Case, you can file a Substantive Appeal to the Board of Veteransa Appeals. When do I file a Substantive Appeal? Youall need to file within one year from the date on the letter notifying you about the original decision on your claim or 60 days from the date on the letter accompanying the Statement of the Case, whichever gives you more time. What do I file? File VA Form 9. Check the status of your appeal by calling 1-800-827-1000 or going online to eBenefits. How the Board of Appeals works: If you selected an optional in-person or video teleconference hearing with a Veterans Law Judge at the Board of Veteransa Appeals, the hearing will be scheduled at your local VA office (or in Washington, DC, if you selected that location). You may request an optional personal hearing before an adjudicator who works at your local VA office or a Veterans Law Judge who works at the Board of Veteransa Appeals. If you request an optional hearing, it will significantly delay a Board decision because optional hearings take more time to schedule. The Veterans Law Judge will make a decision on each issue of your appeal. The decision will grant, remand, or deny each issue. Grant: If an issue is granted, your local VA office will notify you of the decision made by the Board of Veteransa Appeals. Remand: If an issue is remanded, it means that one or more issues in your appeal will be sent back to a local VA office for further evidence collection. Your appeal will return to the Board of Veteransa Appeals when the local VA office complies with the Boardas remand instructions. Deny: If an issue is denied, and you want to pursue further action, you may: File a new claim with your local VA office, File a motion asking the Board of Veteransa Appeals to reconsider your appeal (there is no time limit to file this motion), File a motion asking the Board of Veteransa Appeals to review your appeal again because there was clear and obvious error in its decision (there is no time limit to file this motion), and/or File a Notice of Appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. When? Youall need to file within 120 days from the date of the decision by the Board of Veteransa Appeals (stamped on the first page of the decision). What do I file? File a Notice of Appeal. Send your Notice of Appeal to the Clerk of the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Follow these detailed instructions. Learn more: How Do I Appeal? pamphlet Board of Veterans' Appeals Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. content: Diseases Associated with Agent Orange: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Diseases Associated with Agent Orange//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent OrangeDiseases Associated with Agent Orange VA recognizes the following diseases as related to Agent Orange. If you were exposed, and now have one or more of the diseases listed below, you may be eligible for disability compensation. AL AmyloidosisA rare disease caused when an abnormal protein, amyloid, enters tissues or organs. Chronic B-cell LeukemiaA type of cancer that affects white blood cells. Chloracne (or similar acneform disease)A skin condition that occurs soon after exposure to chemicals and looks like common forms of acne seen in teenagers. Under VAas rating regulations, it must be at least 10% disabling within one year of exposure to herbicides. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2A disease characterized by high blood-sugar levels resulting from the bodyas inability to produce the right levels of the hormone insulin. Hodgkinas DiseaseA malignant lymphoma (cancer) characterized by progressive enlargement of the lymph nodes, liver, and spleen, and by progressive anemia. Ischemic Heart DiseaseA disease characterized by a reduced supply of blood to the heart that results in chest pain. Multiple MyelomaA cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell in bone marrow. Non-Hodgkinas LymphomaA group of cancers that affect the lymph glands and other lymphatic tissue. Parkinsonas DiseaseA progressive disease of the nervous system that affects muscle function. Peripheral Neuropathy, Early OnsetA nervous system condition that causes numbness, tingling, and motor weakness. Under VAas rating regulations, it must be at least 10% disabling within one year of herbicide exposure. Porphyria Cutanea TardaA disorder characterized by liver dysfunction and by thinning and blistering of the skin in sun-exposed areas. Under VAas rating regulations, it must be at least 10% disabling within one year of exposure to herbicides. Prostate CancerCancer of the prostate. Respiratory Cancers (including lung cancer)Cancers of the lung, larynx, trachea, and bronchus. Soft Tissue Sarcomas (other than osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, Kaposias sarcoma, or mesothelioma)Different types of cancers in body tissues such as muscle, fat, blood and lymph vessels, and connective tissues. If you have a disease you think is caused by Agent Orange exposure, but that disease is not listed here, you may still apply for benefits. In these cases, VA requires evidence of disability and medical evidence of a connection between your condition and Agent Orange exposure. VA also considers someA birth defects in children of Vietnam and Korea VeteransA to be associated with Veteransa military service. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Rates//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsRates Apply for Disability Benefits How VA Calculates Compensation Rates The amount of compensation depends on the severity of your disability. VA determines this based on the evidence you send us, as well as the information VA obtains about your disability. VA rates disability from 0% to 100% in 10% increments (for example, 10%, 20%, 30%). See the Combined Ratings page for information about how VA calculates disability percentage for multiple disabilities. You may be paid additional amounts, in certain instances, if: You have very severe disabilities or loss of limb(s). You have a spouse, child(ren), or dependent parent(s). You have a seriously disabled spouse. Veterans Employment Center For Employers Commitments Employers every day are committing to hire Veterans -- you should too! Check out the list below to see what employers have already made a commitment and then create or update your profile to signal your commitment. Of the 14638 registered employers with the Veteran Employment Center(tm): 1439 public commitments made 815973 total positions committed to hire 425048 Veterans hired so far Download all commitments as spreadsheet Employers:Log in to create/manage your hiring commitment. Sign in with LinkedIn Sign in with Google Commitments Company Committed to hire By date Hired so far Walmart Logisticshttp://walmartcareerswithamission.com/who-you-are/transitioning-veterans/ Looking for: various Special commitments to: Veteran Spouse 100000 2018-05-31 40000 Walmart DC 7019 Brundidge, Alabama Looking for: Area Managers for our shipping and receiving department and Operation Managers Special commitments to: Veteran 100000 2018-05-31 67000 Home DepotArizona Looking for: Lot, Cashier,Sales, Freight, Recieving Special commitments to: Veteran Homeless Spouse 65000 2016-12-31 250 Uber Technologies, Inc. https://newsroom.uber.com/2014/09/ubermilitary-we-want-you/ Looking for: Uber Driver Partners Special commitments to: Veteran Homeless Spouse 50000 2016-01-01 41000 Blackstone Headquarters in New York; Porfolio companies across the country Looking for: Positions across our diverse group of portfolio of companies, which include: Hilton, La Quinta, Michaels Stores, GCA, Pinnacle Foods Corporation, Vivint and others. 50000 2019-01-01 10000 UPSAtlanta, GA Looking for: Part time package handlers, delivery drivers, CDL drivers, IT positions, automotive mechanics, Inside Sales Representatives and Finance and Accounting positions Special commitments to: Veteran 50000 2018-12-31 34000 FASTPORT - Hiring Our Heroes Trucking Track Looking for: Trucking Industry Special commitments to: Veteran Spouse 50000 AlliedBarton Security Services120 Offices Nationwide Looking for: Security Officers, Supervisors, Dispatchers Special commitments to: Veteran 25000 2018-04-01 15700 Enterprise HoldingsNationwide Looking for: Sales Management Trainee, IT, Accounting, Automotive Tech/Mechanic, various Customer Service Support roles Special commitments to: Veteran 10000 2020-12-31 2000 Comcast/NBC Universal National Looking for: We offer thousands of different roles at Comcast/NBC Universal from Installation Technician to Sales, Customer service to field operational roles. There are many opportunities! Special commitments to: Veteran Spouse 10000 2017-12-31 2000 Related Info: Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Job Resources Training & Vocational Veterans Opportunity to Work (VOW) Learn more about the Veterans Opportunity to Work (VOW) program and other VA training and career assistance programs. Help make your move from military to civilian life a success - get the training you need to thrive in your next career! See also: Veterans Opportunity to Work (VOW) Credentialing Opportunities On-line (COOL) for Army Solidiers COOL helps Army Soldiers find information on certifications and licenses related to their Military Occupational Specialties (MOSs). See also: COOL (Credentialing Opportunities On-line) for Army Solidiers Credentialing Opportunities On-line (COOL) for Navy Service Members COOL helps Navy Servicemembers find information on certifications and licenses related to enlisted ratings, designators, collateral duties/out of rate assignments, and officer designators. See also: COOL (Credentialing Opportunities On-line) for Navy Service Members On-the-Job & Apprenticeship Training Programs On-the-job (OJT) and apprenticeship training programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r). These programs allow Veterans to learn a trade or skill through training on the job participation rather than attending formal classroom instruction. See also: On-the-Job & Apprenticeship Training Programs United Services Military Apprenticeship Program (USMAP) USMAP is a formal military program that provides active duty Coast Guard, Marine Corps, and Navy Servicemembers the opportunity to improve their job skills and to complete their civilian apprenticeship requirements while on active duty. See also: United Services Military Apprenticeship Program (USMAP) Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VRE) The VR&E program provides services to eligible Veterans with service-connected disabilities prepare for, obtain and maintain suitable employment. Services include career exploration, training and education, and employment services. For Veterans whose disability prevents them from pursuing employment at this time, VR&E also provides Independent Living services. See also: Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VRE) Related Info: Are you a Veteran job seeker? Visit the Job Seeker Section to search jobs, translate your skills, and build a resume. Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. For further guidance visit the U.S. Web design standards. Navigation Vets.gov is launching with a mobile friendly lightweight navigation system. Breadcrumbs Breadcrumb links appear in the header of each content page to help visitor navigate and keep track of their location. Card Navigation Card style navigation is used on topic landing pages to indicate major content areas. List Navigation List navigation links to tertiary and quaternary pages. Quick Links Quick links are used to callout key content or actions for easy access. Footer The footer provides site navigation and key external links. Page Elements Callout Box Callout boxes are used to highlight important content areas and make pages easier to scan. Definition Block Definition blocks help users to quickly identify information that is relevant to them and provide links to more detailed information. Lists Lists can used to decrease content density and organize information. They can be ordered or unordered. Process List The process is an ordered list variation and helps to parse complex tasks into step-by-step instructions. content: U.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in Vietnam: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: U.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in Vietnam//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent OrangeU.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in Vietnam Apply for Disability Benefits U.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in VietnamDates: January 9, 1962 and May 7, 1975 If you served on a Navy or Coast Guard ship in the Vietnam area of operations, you may have been exposed to Agent Orange. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You currently have one or more of these diseases, and You served on ships or boats that were part of the Mobile Riverine Force, Inshore Fire Support Division 93, or had one of the following designations: AGP (Assault Group Patrol/Patrol Craft Tender) LCM (Landing Craft, Mechanized) LCU (Landing Craft, Utility) LCVP (Landing Craft, Vehicle, Personnel) LST (Landing Ship, Tank) PBR (Patrol Boat, River) PCF (Patrol Craft, Fast or Swift Boat) PG (Patrol Gunboat) STABS (Strike Assault Boats) WAK (Cargo Vessel) WHEC (High Endurance Cutter) WLB (Buoy Tender) WPB (Patrol Boat) YFU (Harbor Utility Craft) Note: Even if your vessel is not included in the Mobile Riverine Force, Inshore Fire Support Division 93, or the above designations, it may still appear in VAas alphabetized list of ships that were exposed to Agent Orange. Check to see if your ship was exposed. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Compensation Health An Agent Orange Registry health exam How it works If you served on one of the vessels listed as exposed to Agent Orange, and have one or more of these diseases, VA presumes that your disease is related to Agent Orange exposure in service. If you donat currently have an Agent Orangearelated disability, you and your family may still participate in the Agent Orange Health Registry. Questions Need help determining whether you qualify for benefits?VA will help determine qualifying service in Vietnam after you file a claim for compensation benefits. To contact VA: Call 1-800-827-1000 or 1-800-829-4833 (TDD for hearing impaired). Go to your nearest VA benefits office. Get more information about ships that may have been exposed to Agent Orange. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Job Resources Partnered Resources Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment Policy (ODEP) ODEP's mission is to develop and influence policies and practices that increase the number and quality of employment opportunities for people with disabilities. See also: Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment Policy LinkedIn The LinkedIn instructions for Veteran job seekers provides a comprehensive overview on how Veterans can use LinkedIn to network and find a job. This includes how to establish your identify online, developing a professional network, and finding job opportunities. LinkedIn is also providing a free 1-year Job Seeker subscription ($360 value) to all U.S. Veterans and ServiceMembers. Register here. See also: LinkedIn Instructions for Veterans and Tips for Veteran Job Seekers Coursera Coursera is an educational platform providing over 800 courses in a wide variety of disciplines from accredited schools and institutions worldwide, including but not limited to information technology, business and management, and education. All course material is available free of charge, and additionally, Coursera provides all Veterans with free certification upon completion of any Coursera course that you chose choose to take. See also: Coursera for Vets Career One Stop Career One Stop is an online resource sponsored by the U.S. Department of Labor. Career One Stop has tools to help job seekers, students, businesses, and career professionals. Some of the information and resources available include career search and exploration, information on education and training, Resume and interview advice, and many more. See also: Career One Stop Soldier for Life Soldier for Life supports successful reintegration of our Soldiers, Veterans and their families by promoting connections with a wide variety of government and community resources. to keep them ARMY STRONG and instill their values, ethos, and leadership within the communities. See also: Soldier for Life American Job Centers More than 2,500 AJCs in communities nationwide provide job seekers with free help for a variety of career and employment-related needs. Free services vary by location, but typically include: telephones and internet service, resume help, job-training services and workshops, job-search assistance, career counseling, skills testing, labor market and employer information, hiring events, and referrals to community resources and social services. See also: Find American Job Centers Near You MyNextMove MyNextMove is a valuable resource provided by the Department of Labor. It assists job seekers in answering the question "What do you want to do for a living?" See also: MyNextMove USDA USDA is ready to help you take the first step in the agriculture industry. USDA offers a variety of programs that are available to help Veterans get started as a new farmer or rancher. New Farmers Related Info: Are you a Veteran job seeker? Visit the Job Seeker Section to search jobs, translate your skills, and build a resume. Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. content: Correspondence Training: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Correspondence Training//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsWork and LearnNon-Traditional OptionsCorrespondence Training If you would like to learn at home or are located in a remote area, correspondence training may be a good option for you. This type of training does not have to be completed within a quarter, semester, or term. You receive coursework assignments in the mail and send them back when completed. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You meet the basic requirements for any GI BillA(r) program. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Reimbursed expenses. (Read more below.) How it works Participation requirements are the same for all GI BillA(r) programs, though the payment amount varies depending on the specific GI BillA(r) program you are using. If you are enrolled in correspondence training, VA determines your payment amount and pays it quarterly after receiving certification of lessons completed from the school. For Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) recipients, VA reimburses the actual costs of the schoolas in-state tuition and fees, up to the maximum amount allowed by law. View the current payment rates. For all other GI BillA(r) recipients, VA reimburses 55% of the approved costs. Exception: This assistance is not available for children training under the Dependentsa Educational Assistance program. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillUndergraduate and Graduate Degrees If you would like to earn an advanced degree at an institution of higher learning, including four-year universities, community colleges, and schools offering advanced degrees, VA education and training benefits may be available to you. The number of classes you attend and the accompanying hours spent in those classes determine your payments. For example, for most undergraduate degrees, a college considers: 12 or more hours full time 9-11 hours three-quarter time 6-8 hours half time Less than six hours as reimbursable at a rate thatas no more than the tuition and fees charged for the course(s) If you are interested in graduate-level training, the school determines how each hour is rated. For example, if a two-hour class is considered full time in a graduate program at your school, VA will pay you the full-time rate. You can attend more than one college at a time under the GI Bill as long as the classes at both institutions count toward your degree, and the school granting your degree accepts the classes at the second school as part of your requirements. However, the GI Bill will not pay you to take the same class twice, unless you receive a failing grade in a class that is a graduation requirement. The GI Bill can pay you for the classes required to achieve more than one degree. Once you earn a degree, you could pursue another one if you have remaining entitlement on your GI Bill. VA issues payments after each monthas classes. For example, you receive the November payment in December. For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the tuition and fees are paid directly to the school, the book stipend is paid to you at the beginning of the term, and the housing allowance is paid to you at the end of each month. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Post-9/11 GI Bill: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Post-9/11 GI Bill//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillPost-9/11 GI Bill If you are seeking education or training opportunities and have served on active duty after September 10, 2001, you may be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill. The Post-9/11 GI Bill is the largest expansion of education benefits since the Montgomery GI Bill. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You meet the basic requirements for any GI Bill program. You have served on active duty for at least 90 days, whether continuous or interrupted, after September 10, 2001. If you are eligible for more than one VA education benefit, you may be asked to make an irrevocable election. Making an airrevocable electiona means that you cannot change back to another GI Bill program for which you may also be eligible after you receive Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Tuition and fees A monthly housing allowance (for those attending more than half time) A books and supplies stipend (up to $1,000 per academic year) How it works The benefit amount varies according to where you use the benefit, the amount of your active-duty service since September 10, 2001, and how many credits or training hours you are taking. The program Covers the entire in-state tuition for state schools and up to the national maximum ($21,084.89) for private or foreign schools. Pays eligible individuals a Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) based on the cost of living for the specific location of your school. Example: If you were attending University of California, Los Angeles, in 2015 (at the 100% benefit level, while attending school full time), you would receive a BAH of up to $2,433 a month while in school. If you were attending the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, you would receive up to $1,638 while in school. Provides up to 36 months of educational benefits, generally payable for 15 years following your release from active duty Uses a percentage-of-maximum-benefit scale based on how much active service you have had since September 10, 2001 Example: If you had 90 days of active service since September 10, 2001, you would qualify for 40% of the maximum amount. Three years of active service would qualify you for 100% of the benefit. Other potential benefits The Yellow Ribbon Program may provide additional support to cover higher private-school and out-of-state tuition and fees. The Transfer of Entitlement option enables eligible Servicemembers to transfer all 36 months or a portion of Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to a spouse or children. Transfer eligibility is determined by the Department of Defense. Use the GI Bill Comparison Tool to pick the right type of educational assistance program and school to maximize your benefits. Get information about the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship (Fry Scholarship) for dependents of Servicemembers who died in the line of duty after September 10, 2001. Types of training The following types of programs and courses may be used under the Post-9/11 GI Bill: Correspondence training Cooperative training Entrepreneurship training Flight training Independent and distance learning Institutions of higher learning undergraduate and graduate degrees Licensing and certification reimbursement Vocational/technical training and non-college degree programs National testing reimbursement On-the-job training Tuition Assistance Top-Up Tutorial Assistance Learn more See the current payment rates for the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) pamphlet Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) aGI BillA(r) is a registered trademark of the United States Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). The absence of the registration symbol A(r) does not constitute a waiver of VAas trademark rights in that phrase.a Read our Terms of Use. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Rates: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Rates//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsRates Apply for Disability Benefits How VA Calculates Compensation Rates The amount of compensation depends on the severity of your disability. VA determines this based on the evidence you send us, as well as the information VA obtains about your disability. VA rates disability from 0% to 100% in 10% increments (for example, 10%, 20%, 30%). See the Combined Ratings page for information about how VA calculates disability percentage for multiple disabilities. You may be paid additional amounts, in certain instances, if: You have very severe disabilities or loss of limb(s). You have a spouse, child(ren), or dependent parent(s). You have a seriously disabled spouse. content: Editorial Guide: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Editorial Guide//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> PlaybookEditorial GuideEditorial GuideEditorial Principles and Style Language communicates our humanity.A In the context of a website, it conjures up the people on the other side of that glowing screen. It engages, builds trust, and guides visitors through processes and information that can be stressful and confusing.The primary headline on our home page reflects that: How can we help?Vets.govas language is clear and direct, yet its tone is warm and quiet. We respect Veteransa time, so we get to the point. And we avoid bureaucratese.We donat say utilize when use works just as well.We avoid saying manifested, because started says it better.We distill and simplify. Weare not selling programs and benefits, but rather helping Veterans and their families understand whether a benefit is right for them so they can make informed choices about how to proceed. Our goal is to give Veterans and their families the information they need to make important decisions confidently, easilyaand done.Additional ResourcesThe Veterans Benefit Administration Style Guide (PDF)The Veterans Health Administration Style Guide (PDF)The Chicago Manual of Style Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Non-College Degree Program: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Non-College Degree Program//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsWork and LearnNon-College Degree Program If you are a Veteran, Servicemember, or eligible dependent interested in non-college degree programs (such as EMT, HVAC repair, truck driving, and more), the GI BillA(r) may pay all or a portion of your tuition. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You qualify for the GI BillA(r). You enroll, or plan to enroll, in a non-degree program at an approved institution. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Significant tuition assistance Books and supplies stipend How it works Benefits depend on which GI BillA(r) program you use and the school you attend. VA pays you at the end of each month for the hours you have spent training, and provides a monthly housing allowance based on the location of the school. You may receive up to $83 per month for books and supplies. Post-9/11 GI BillA(r): For training offered at non-degree schools, VA pays for in-state tuition and fees up to the national maximum. Other GI BillA(r) programs: VA pays a monthly rate that depends on your specific program and your length of active service. View current payment rates. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Resume Builder Already have a profile saved on vets.gov? Sign in to access it. Build a Profile & Resume Use this form to create a public profile so employers committed to hiring Veterans can find you here on the Veterans Employment Center(tm). Manually enter your information into the form fields below, or use the Auto-fill from LinkedIn button to pre-populate some of the fields from your LinkedIn account. (Not all fields will be populated). Auto-fill from LinkedIn LinkedIn is also providing a free 1-year Job Seeker Premium subscription ($360 value) to all U.S. Veterans and Servicemembers. Learn more here. (This section is required for Federal job applications) Add the basics Enter your name Your Name Your Email Required State Your Objectives Enter basic information about your career goals and objectives. 1 - 2 sentences about your qualifications and career objectives. This appears in search results, so make it stand out! (This section is required for Federal job applications) When can you start work? When can you start work? Available (estimate) as of (MM/DD/YYYY) Your Civilian Skills Add your civilian skills. Add as many as necessary by using the autocomplete field Add a new skill (press enter to add): + Add Another Skill (This section is required for Federal job applications) Education & Training Add your education information. Add as many as necessary by using the add education experience link. Name of school or training Type of credential earned Please select oneSome High School CourseworkHigh School or equivalentTechnical or Occupational CertificateAssociate's DegreeSome College Coursework CompletedBachelor's DegreeMaster's DegreeDoctorateProfessional Credential topic Description Start date (MM/DD/YYYY) End date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if you are still completing this education) + Add Education Experience Military Service Add your military information. Add as many as necessary by using the add military experience link below. Military Occupation Code Duty Station Branch of Service Rank Please select your rankE-1E-2E-3E-4E-5E-6E-7E-8E-9W-1W-2W-3W-4W-5O-1O-2O-3O-4O-5O-6O-7O-8O-9O-10 Title Describe Your Position Responsibilities Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Military Experience Work Experience Add your employment information. Add as many as necessary by using the Add work experience link below. (This section is required for Federal job applications) Position Organization Describe Your Position Responsibilities Hours/Week Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Work Experience Volunteer Experience Add your work experience. Add as many as necessary by using the Add volunteer experience link. Position Organization Description Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Volunteer Experience Awards Enter your award information. Add as many as necessary by using the Add award link. Name of Award Awarding Organization Date Received (MM/DD/YYYY) + Add Award Professional Affiliations Enter your job title information Affiliation Affiliated Organization + Add Affiliation (This section is required for Federal job applications) References Add your professional references. Add as many as necessary by using the add reference link. Name Email Title + Add Reference Location Preference Enter your location preferences below. Add as many as necessary by using the Add another location link. (For the best employment search results, specify one or more cities rather than just a state or country.) Desired Location + Add Location Other Enter optional additional information to assist potential employers in finding your profile. Indicate any special categories that apply to you: Caretaker Family Member Guard/Reservist Smooth Takeoff Project Junior Military Officer (O1-O4) Service-Connected Disabled Veteran Service-Connected Disabled Veteran (10%) Service-Connected Disabled Veteran (30%) Transitioning Servicemember Military Spouse Veteran Save As Draft Let employers find and view your profile, or save it as a draft. Check this box if you DON'T want employers to find and view your profile. Save as draft Your profile will only be visible to employers after you log in to save your information. Some may not be apparent until years after you have completed your service.A disability can apply to physical conditions, such as chronic knee pain, as well as mental-health conditions, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).ConditionsWhat conditions qualify me for benefits?RatesHow does VA calculate compensation rates?Claims processHow does the claims process work?AppealsWhat if I disagree with my rating decision?Apply for Benefits Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Hospitalization: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Hospitalization//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsSpecial ClaimsHospitalization Apply for Disability Benefits If you were hospitalized for a service-connected disability at a VA or VA-approved facility, you may be eligible to receive a temporary 100% disability rating for the time you spent in the hospital. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You were hospitalized for more than 21 days in a VA hospital or other approved hospital for a service-connected disability, or You were under hospital observation for more than 21 days at VA expense for a service-connected disability. Who is covered You Available benefits Compensation Health care How it works If you were not hospitalized at a VA facility, you should provide the hospital discharge summary showing the length of stay and cause for hospitalization when filing your claim. Example A Veteran with a 40% service-connected disability rating for diabetes mellitus was hospitalized at a VA facility after lapsing into a diabetic coma. He required 25 days of hospitalization due to the coma and associated infections. VA temporarily raised his rating to 100% for the period of his hospitalization. After this period, his disability rating reverted to 40%.
