Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Job Resources Training & Vocational Veterans Opportunity to Work (VOW) Learn more about the Veterans Opportunity to Work (VOW) program and other VA training and career assistance programs. Help make your move from military to civilian life a success - get the training you need to thrive in your next career! See also: Veterans Opportunity to Work (VOW) Credentialing Opportunities On-line (COOL) for Army Solidiers COOL helps Army Soldiers find information on certifications and licenses related to their Military Occupational Specialties (MOSs). See also: COOL (Credentialing Opportunities On-line) for Army Solidiers Credentialing Opportunities On-line (COOL) for Navy Service Members COOL helps Navy Servicemembers find information on certifications and licenses related to enlisted ratings, designators, collateral duties/out of rate assignments, and officer designators. See also: COOL (Credentialing Opportunities On-line) for Navy Service Members On-the-Job & Apprenticeship Training Programs On-the-job (OJT) and apprenticeship training programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r). These programs allow Veterans to learn a trade or skill through training on the job participation rather than attending formal classroom instruction. See also: On-the-Job & Apprenticeship Training Programs United Services Military Apprenticeship Program (USMAP) USMAP is a formal military program that provides active duty Coast Guard, Marine Corps, and Navy Servicemembers the opportunity to improve their job skills and to complete their civilian apprenticeship requirements while on active duty. See also: United Services Military Apprenticeship Program (USMAP) Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VRE) The VR&E program provides services to eligible Veterans with service-connected disabilities prepare for, obtain and maintain suitable employment. Services include career exploration, training and education, and employment services. For Veterans whose disability prevents them from pursuing employment at this time, VR&E also provides Independent Living services. See also: Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VRE) Related Info: Are you a Veteran job seeker? Visit the Job Seeker Section to search jobs, translate your skills, and build a resume. Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. For further guidance visit the U.S. Web design standards. Navigation Vets.gov is launching with a mobile friendly lightweight navigation system. Breadcrumbs Breadcrumb links appear in the header of each content page to help visitor navigate and keep track of their location. Card Navigation Card style navigation is used on topic landing pages to indicate major content areas. List Navigation List navigation links to tertiary and quaternary pages. Quick Links Quick links are used to callout key content or actions for easy access. Footer The footer provides site navigation and key external links. Page Elements Callout Box Callout boxes are used to highlight important content areas and make pages easier to scan. Definition Block Definition blocks help users to quickly identify information that is relevant to them and provide links to more detailed information. Lists Lists can used to decrease content density and organize information. They can be ordered or unordered. Process List The process is an ordered list variation and helps to parse complex tasks into step-by-step instructions. content: U.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in Vietnam: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: U.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in Vietnam//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent OrangeU.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in Vietnam Apply for Disability Benefits U.S. Navy and Coast Guard Ships in VietnamDates: January 9, 1962 and May 7, 1975 If you served on a Navy or Coast Guard ship in the Vietnam area of operations, you may have been exposed to Agent Orange. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You currently have one or more of these diseases, and You served on ships or boats that were part of the Mobile Riverine Force, Inshore Fire Support Division 93, or had one of the following designations: AGP (Assault Group Patrol/Patrol Craft Tender) LCM (Landing Craft, Mechanized) LCU (Landing Craft, Utility) LCVP (Landing Craft, Vehicle, Personnel) LST (Landing Ship, Tank) PBR (Patrol Boat, River) PCF (Patrol Craft, Fast or Swift Boat) PG (Patrol Gunboat) STABS (Strike Assault Boats) WAK (Cargo Vessel) WHEC (High Endurance Cutter) WLB (Buoy Tender) WPB (Patrol Boat) YFU (Harbor Utility Craft) Note: Even if your vessel is not included in the Mobile Riverine Force, Inshore Fire Support Division 93, or the above designations, it may still appear in VAas alphabetized list of ships that were exposed to Agent Orange. Check to see if your ship was exposed. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Compensation Health An Agent Orange Registry health exam How it works If you served on one of the vessels listed as exposed to Agent Orange, and have one or more of these diseases, VA presumes that your disease is related to Agent Orange exposure in service. If you donat currently have an Agent Orangearelated disability, you and your family may still participate in the Agent Orange Health Registry. Questions Need help determining whether you qualify for benefits?VA will help determine qualifying service in Vietnam after you file a claim for compensation benefits. To contact VA: Call 1-800-827-1000 or 1-800-829-4833 (TDD for hearing impaired). Go to your nearest VA benefits office. Get more information about ships that may have been exposed to Agent Orange. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Job Resources Partnered Resources Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment Policy (ODEP) ODEP's mission is to develop and influence policies and practices that increase the number and quality of employment opportunities for people with disabilities. See also: Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment Policy LinkedIn The LinkedIn instructions for Veteran job seekers provides a comprehensive overview on how Veterans can use LinkedIn to network and find a job. This includes how to establish your identify online, developing a professional network, and finding job opportunities. LinkedIn is also providing a free 1-year Job Seeker subscription ($360 value) to all U.S. Veterans and ServiceMembers. Register here. See also: LinkedIn Instructions for Veterans and Tips for Veteran Job Seekers Coursera Coursera is an educational platform providing over 800 courses in a wide variety of disciplines from accredited schools and institutions worldwide, including but not limited to information technology, business and management, and education. All course material is available free of charge, and additionally, Coursera provides all Veterans with free certification upon completion of any Coursera course that you chose choose to take. See also: Coursera for Vets Career One Stop Career One Stop is an online resource sponsored by the U.S. Department of Labor. Career One Stop has tools to help job seekers, students, businesses, and career professionals. Some of the information and resources available include career search and exploration, information on education and training, Resume and interview advice, and many more. See also: Career One Stop Soldier for Life Soldier for Life supports successful reintegration of our Soldiers, Veterans and their families by promoting connections with a wide variety of government and community resources. to keep them ARMY STRONG and instill their values, ethos, and leadership within the communities. See also: Soldier for Life American Job Centers More than 2,500 AJCs in communities nationwide provide job seekers with free help for a variety of career and employment-related needs. Free services vary by location, but typically include: telephones and internet service, resume help, job-training services and workshops, job-search assistance, career counseling, skills testing, labor market and employer information, hiring events, and referrals to community resources and social services. See also: Find American Job Centers Near You MyNextMove MyNextMove is a valuable resource provided by the Department of Labor. It assists job seekers in answering the question "What do you want to do for a living?" See also: MyNextMove USDA USDA is ready to help you take the first step in the agriculture industry. USDA offers a variety of programs that are available to help Veterans get started as a new farmer or rancher. New Farmers Related Info: Are you a Veteran job seeker? Visit the Job Seeker Section to search jobs, translate your skills, and build a resume. Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. content: Correspondence Training: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Correspondence Training//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsWork and LearnNon-Traditional OptionsCorrespondence Training If you would like to learn at home or are located in a remote area, correspondence training may be a good option for you. This type of training does not have to be completed within a quarter, semester, or term. You receive coursework assignments in the mail and send them back when completed. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You meet the basic requirements for any GI BillA(r) program. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Reimbursed expenses. (Read more below.) How it works Participation requirements are the same for all GI BillA(r) programs, though the payment amount varies depending on the specific GI BillA(r) program you are using. If you are enrolled in correspondence training, VA determines your payment amount and pays it quarterly after receiving certification of lessons completed from the school. For Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) recipients, VA reimburses the actual costs of the schoolas in-state tuition and fees, up to the maximum amount allowed by law. View the current payment rates. For all other GI BillA(r) recipients, VA reimburses 55% of the approved costs. Exception: This assistance is not available for children training under the Dependentsa Educational Assistance program. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Undergraduate and Graduate Degrees//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillUndergraduate and Graduate Degrees If you would like to earn an advanced degree at an institution of higher learning, including four-year universities, community colleges, and schools offering advanced degrees, VA education and training benefits may be available to you. The number of classes you attend and the accompanying hours spent in those classes determine your payments. For example, for most undergraduate degrees, a college considers: 12 or more hours full time 9-11 hours three-quarter time 6-8 hours half time Less than six hours as reimbursable at a rate thatas no more than the tuition and fees charged for the course(s) If you are interested in graduate-level training, the school determines how each hour is rated. For example, if a two-hour class is considered full time in a graduate program at your school, VA will pay you the full-time rate. You can attend more than one college at a time under the GI Bill as long as the classes at both institutions count toward your degree, and the school granting your degree accepts the classes at the second school as part of your requirements. However, the GI Bill will not pay you to take the same class twice, unless you receive a failing grade in a class that is a graduation requirement. The GI Bill can pay you for the classes required to achieve more than one degree. Once you earn a degree, you could pursue another one if you have remaining entitlement on your GI Bill. VA issues payments after each monthas classes. For example, you receive the November payment in December. For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the tuition and fees are paid directly to the school, the book stipend is paid to you at the beginning of the term, and the housing allowance is paid to you at the end of each month. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Post-9/11 GI Bill: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Post-9/11 GI Bill//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsGI BillPost-9/11 GI Bill If you are seeking education or training opportunities and have served on active duty after September 10, 2001, you may be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill. The Post-9/11 GI Bill is the largest expansion of education benefits since the Montgomery GI Bill. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You meet the basic requirements for any GI Bill program. You have served on active duty for at least 90 days, whether continuous or interrupted, after September 10, 2001. If you are eligible for more than one VA education benefit, you may be asked to make an irrevocable election. Making an airrevocable electiona means that you cannot change back to another GI Bill program for which you may also be eligible after you receive Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits. Who is covered You and your dependents Available benefits Tuition and fees A monthly housing allowance (for those attending more than half time) A books and supplies stipend (up to $1,000 per academic year) How it works The benefit amount varies according to where you use the benefit, the amount of your active-duty service since September 10, 2001, and how many credits or training hours you are taking. The program Covers the entire in-state tuition for state schools and up to the national maximum ($21,084.89) for private or foreign schools. Pays eligible individuals a Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) based on the cost of living for the specific location of your school. Example: If you were attending University of California, Los Angeles, in 2015 (at the 100% benefit level, while attending school full time), you would receive a BAH of up to $2,433 a month while in school. If you were attending the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, you would receive up to $1,638 while in school. Provides up to 36 months of educational benefits, generally payable for 15 years following your release from active duty Uses a percentage-of-maximum-benefit scale based on how much active service you have had since September 10, 2001 Example: If you had 90 days of active service since September 10, 2001, you would qualify for 40% of the maximum amount. Three years of active service would qualify you for 100% of the benefit. Other potential benefits The Yellow Ribbon Program may provide additional support to cover higher private-school and out-of-state tuition and fees. The Transfer of Entitlement option enables eligible Servicemembers to transfer all 36 months or a portion of Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to a spouse or children. Transfer eligibility is determined by the Department of Defense. Use the GI Bill Comparison Tool to pick the right type of educational assistance program and school to maximize your benefits. Get information about the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship (Fry Scholarship) for dependents of Servicemembers who died in the line of duty after September 10, 2001. Types of training The following types of programs and courses may be used under the Post-9/11 GI Bill: Correspondence training Cooperative training Entrepreneurship training Flight training Independent and distance learning Institutions of higher learning undergraduate and graduate degrees Licensing and certification reimbursement Vocational/technical training and non-college degree programs National testing reimbursement On-the-job training Tuition Assistance Top-Up Tutorial Assistance Learn more See the current payment rates for the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) Post-9/11 GI BillA(r) pamphlet Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) aGI BillA(r) is a registered trademark of the United States Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). The absence of the registration symbol A(r) does not constitute a waiver of VAas trademark rights in that phrase.a Read our Terms of Use. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Rates: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Rates//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsRates Apply for Disability Benefits How VA Calculates Compensation Rates The amount of compensation depends on the severity of your disability. VA determines this based on the evidence you send us, as well as the information VA obtains about your disability. VA rates disability from 0% to 100% in 10% increments (for example, 10%, 20%, 30%). See the Combined Ratings page for information about how VA calculates disability percentage for multiple disabilities. You may be paid additional amounts, in certain instances, if: You have very severe disabilities or loss of limb(s). You have a spouse, child(ren), or dependent parent(s). You have a seriously disabled spouse. content: Editorial Guide: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Editorial Guide//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> PlaybookEditorial GuideEditorial GuideEditorial Principles and Style Language communicates our humanity.A In the context of a website, it conjures up the people on the other side of that glowing screen. It engages, builds trust, and guides visitors through processes and information that can be stressful and confusing.The primary headline on our home page reflects that: How can we help?Vets.govas language is clear and direct, yet its tone is warm and quiet. We respect Veteransa time, so we get to the point. And we avoid bureaucratese.We donat say utilize when use works just as well.We avoid saying manifested, because started says it better.We distill and simplify. Weare not selling programs and benefits, but rather helping Veterans and their families understand whether a benefit is right for them so they can make informed choices about how to proceed. Our goal is to give Veterans and their families the information they need to make important decisions confidently, easilyaand done.Additional ResourcesThe Veterans Benefit Administration Style Guide (PDF)The Veterans Health Administration Style Guide (PDF)The Chicago Manual of Style Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Resume Builder Already have a profile saved on vets.gov? Sign in to access it. Build a Profile & Resume Use this form to create a public profile so employers committed to hiring Veterans can find you here on the Veterans Employment Center(tm). Manually enter your information into the form fields below, or use the Auto-fill from LinkedIn button to pre-populate some of the fields from your LinkedIn account. (Not all fields will be populated). Auto-fill from LinkedIn LinkedIn is also providing a free 1-year Job Seeker Premium subscription ($360 value) to all U.S. Veterans and Servicemembers. Learn more here. (This section is required for Federal job applications) Add the basics Enter your name Your Name Your Email Required State Your Objectives Enter basic information about your career goals and objectives. 1 - 2 sentences about your qualifications and career objectives. This appears in search results, so make it stand out! (This section is required for Federal job applications) When can you start work? When can you start work? Available (estimate) as of (MM/DD/YYYY) Your Civilian Skills Add your civilian skills. Add as many as necessary by using the autocomplete field Add a new skill (press enter to add): + Add Another Skill (This section is required for Federal job applications) Education & Training Add your education information. Add as many as necessary by using the add education experience link. Name of school or training Type of credential earned Please select oneSome High School CourseworkHigh School or equivalentTechnical or Occupational CertificateAssociate's DegreeSome College Coursework CompletedBachelor's DegreeMaster's DegreeDoctorateProfessional Credential topic Description Start date (MM/DD/YYYY) End date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if you are still completing this education) + Add Education Experience Military Service Add your military information. Add as many as necessary by using the add military experience link below. Military Occupation Code Duty Station Branch of Service Rank Please select your rankE-1E-2E-3E-4E-5E-6E-7E-8E-9W-1W-2W-3W-4W-5O-1O-2O-3O-4O-5O-6O-7O-8O-9O-10 Title Describe Your Position Responsibilities Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Military Experience Work Experience Add your employment information. Add as many as necessary by using the Add work experience link below. (This section is required for Federal job applications) Position Organization Describe Your Position Responsibilities Hours/Week Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Work Experience Volunteer Experience Add your work experience. Add as many as necessary by using the Add volunteer experience link. Position Organization Description Start Date (MM/DD/YYYY) End Date (MM/DD/YYYY) (leave blank if present) + Add Volunteer Experience Awards Enter your award information. Add as many as necessary by using the Add award link. Name of Award Awarding Organization Date Received (MM/DD/YYYY) + Add Award Professional Affiliations Enter your job title information Affiliation Affiliated Organization + Add Affiliation (This section is required for Federal job applications) References Add your professional references. Add as many as necessary by using the add reference link. Name Email Title + Add Reference Location Preference Enter your location preferences below. Add as many as necessary by using the Add another location link. (For the best employment search results, specify one or more cities rather than just a state or country.) Desired Location + Add Location Other Enter optional additional information to assist potential employers in finding your profile. Indicate any special categories that apply to you: Caretaker Family Member Guard/Reservist Smooth Takeoff Project Junior Military Officer (O1-O4) Service-Connected Disabled Veteran Service-Connected Disabled Veteran (10%) Service-Connected Disabled Veteran (30%) Transitioning Servicemember Military Spouse Veteran Save As Draft Let employers find and view your profile, or save it as a draft. Check this box if you DON'T want employers to find and view your profile. Save as draft Your profile will only be visible to employers after you log in to save your information. Some may not be apparent until years after you have completed your service.A disability can apply to physical conditions, such as chronic knee pain, as well as mental-health conditions, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).ConditionsWhat conditions qualify me for benefits?RatesHow does VA calculate compensation rates?Claims processHow does the claims process work?AppealsWhat if I disagree with my rating decision?Apply for Benefits Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. content: Hospitalization: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Hospitalization//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsSpecial ClaimsHospitalization Apply for Disability Benefits If you were hospitalized for a service-connected disability at a VA or VA-approved facility, you may be eligible to receive a temporary 100% disability rating for the time you spent in the hospital. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You were hospitalized for more than 21 days in a VA hospital or other approved hospital for a service-connected disability, or You were under hospital observation for more than 21 days at VA expense for a service-connected disability. Who is covered You Available benefits Compensation Health care How it works If you were not hospitalized at a VA facility, you should provide the hospital discharge summary showing the length of stay and cause for hospitalization when filing your claim. Example A Veteran with a 40% service-connected disability rating for diabetes mellitus was hospitalized at a VA facility after lapsing into a diabetic coma. He required 25 days of hospitalization due to the coma and associated infections. VA temporarily raised his rating to 100% for the period of his hospitalization. After this period, his disability rating reverted to 40%. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Product Methodology: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Product Methodology//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Product Methodology Process Vets.gov combines human centered design with agile development to deliver products grounded in customer need and supported through cycles of continuous improvement This methodology is intended for teams designing new products for vets.gov and for those migrating existing tools and content from VA websites. The framework, while not prescriptive, is a best practice model that aligns human-centered design with the vets.gov development and migration process. The activities of cross-functional teams are detailed out by phase as well as specific VA stakeholder engagement points with the Vets.gov team. HCD Discover Project definition An outline of the projectas key components. This should include a description of the current environment. Learn about Project Definition Kickoff The kickoff meeting is conducted after completion of project definition and brings together the entire project team. It creates alignment and shared understanding of the projectas goals, scope, milestones, roles and responsibilities. It builds on the project definition phase by eliciting known business requirements, user needs and technical platform dependencies. Learn about Kickoff Discovery Discovery validates and expands upon the initial project definition. Deeper understanding is developed through design research focused on business and customer needs. Technical investigation also happens in this phase. These activities serve as the foundation for product concept exploration. Learn about Discovery Design Alpha: Design, Prototype & Plana" iterative cycle Alpha kicks off the iterative design and development process. Here, insights from the discovery phase inform product and concept prototypes. These are tested with real users to validate and refine the approach. Learn about Alpha Beta: Iterate and Build iterative cycle Beta continues the iterative process, with increasing refinements moving toward a fully functional live product with solid back-end integration. Learn about Beta Deliver Measure Refine Pre-Flight The preflight check ensures critical 508 accessibility and transparency requirements have been met and that business sign-off has occurred before the product is public. Learn about Pre-flight Go Live iterative cycle a"Go Live is the point at which a Vets.Gov product is pushed to the public. Products undergo a process of continuous improvement in response to ongoing customer feedback and the addition of new capabilities. Learn about Go Live Sunset a"Existing VA products will need to be retired after they are re-designed and brought into the platform. Care should be taken to communicate these changes to users and to help them transition as needed. Learn about Sunset Operations and Maintenance (O&M) iterative cycle a"Operations and maintenance is the process through which a live product is sustained and enhanced. It includes maintenance cycles and continuous improvement along with a defined workflow to support changes and ongoing requirements. Learn about Operations and Maintenance Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. content: What is Quick Start?: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: What is Quick Start?//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPredischargeWhat is Quick Start? Apply for Disability Benefits If you are in predischarge status between 1 and 59 days before separation, retirement, or release from active duty or demobilization, Quick Start allows you to submit a claim for disability compensation. Are you eligible for benefits? Yes, if: You have a known separation date. Your separation date is 1 to 59 days away. You are full-time Active Duty, National Guard, or Reserves. Who is covered You Available benefits Expedited status decision on your disability claim How it works By submitting your disability compensation claim before discharge, you can receive VA disability benefits as soon as possible after separation, retirement, or demobilization. You must submit your service-treatment records to VA when you submit your claim, and you must complete all phases of the VA/DOD medical separation examination process at your point of separation and before you are released from the military. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Discover//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Product Methodology Discover Step 3: Discovery Discovery validates and expands upon the initial project definition. Deeper understanding is developed through design research focused on business and customer needs. Technical investigation also happens in this phase. These activities serve as the foundation for product concept exploration. Outputs Discovery Report i Leads Project Team POC Project Team Leads VA Product Lead Participants Engineering Full stack engineer Site reliability engineer Front-end developer Engineering lead Data scientist Content Strategist VA Product Lead VA Content Writers VA SMEs Design researcher UX Designer VA Stakeholder Engagement Participate in working sessions to provide business requirements, validate design concepts, and provide feedback to vets.gov team as needed. Provide requested documentation and timely responses to questions as requested. Provide introductions / access to end users as available. Provide any available feedback or data about end users Develop launch communication plan Provide input for sunset strategy for systems and content Engineering Identify all required data elements. Identify data collection needs and data-driven goals. (For example, tracking completion rates for a form, or top search terms.) Identify related systems. Plan for rebuild, or integration. (For example, sending an electronic disability claim.) Define system architecture including data, security, integrations and services Search Identify current user search terms on Google, VA.gov Identify initial keyword list Content Define goals for content. What do users need? Review existing content, online and off. What can be incorporated? What needs to be newly created? Define feature set a the content elements that will be included in this release. Use Vets.gov Style Guide in creating new content and revising any thatas reused. Design Research Review existing research to determine how much additional research is required. Create a research plan Conduct research Synthesize findings Document findings Share with larger core vets.gov team and with the business partner team Design Heuristic audit Back: Kickoff Next: Alpha: Design, Prototype & Plana" Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Veterans Employment Center(tm) The Veterans Employment Center(tm) connects Veterans and their families with meaningful employment and career development opportunities. Resources and tools for both job seekers and employers. Job Seekers Map your military skills, build a civilian resume, and post your profile so employers will easily find you. Search our career opportunities, and learn about organizations that can assist you with career development and employment. Employers Access Veterans who are seeking employment directly by searching verified profiles of Veterans and their spouses. Post open positions. Make a public hiring commitment. Access Veteran experience and skills and hire the best! Veterans Employment Center For Job Seekers Job Resources Education & Counseling VA Educational & Career Counseling The VA can help eligible Servicemembers and Veterans determine what educational and career opportunities are best suited for you. Combining your hard work with an in-depth skill profile and up-to-date career path information will launch you towards success you want and deserve in your career. See also: Educational & Career Counseling (Chapter 36) The GI Bill(r) Enhance your career path with education and training resources. As a Veteran, you may be eligible for educational benefits through numerous GI Bill programs. See also: GI Bill(r) VA Campus Toolkit Are you a Veteran enrolled in higher education or thinking about higher education? The VA Campus Toolkit has a variety of information for you, including how to find and access support. See also: VA Campus Toolkit Veterans Employment Toolkit Information and resources to help employers, managers and supervisors, human resource professionals, and employee assistance program (EAP) providers relate to and support their employees who are Veterans and members of the Reserve and National Guard. See also: Veterans Employment Toolkit VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC) The VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC) program aims to help Veterans, Service members, and their qualified dependents succeed and thrive through a coordinated delivery of on-campus benefits assistance and counseling, leading to completion of their education and preparing them to enter the labor market in viable careers. The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is developing innovative ways to help Veterans make the transition to college life. The VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC) program aims to help Veterans, Servicemembers, and their qualified dependents succeed and thrive through a coordinated delivery of on-campus benefits assistance and counseling, leading to completion of their education and preparing them to enter the labor market in viable careers. The VSOC program provides a VA Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC) to each VSOC school. These VRCs are called VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC) Counselors. A VA Vet Center Outreach Coordinator is also provided, and co-located on many campuses, to provide peer-to-peer counseling and referral services. Through the VSOC program, VA is strengthening partnerships with institutions of higher learning and creating opportunities to help Veterans achieve success by providing outreach and transition services during their transition from military to college life. VSOC Counselors ensure that Veterans receive the support and assistance needed to pursue their educational and employment goals. Because VSOC Counselors are easily accessible on campus they help resolve any problems that could potentially interfere with a Veteran's educational program, to include assisting with disability accommodations. If needed, they can also provide referrals for health services through VA Medical Centers, Community-Based Outpatient Clinics, or Vet Centers. The VSOC program began as a pilot program in 2009 at the University of South Florida. The VSOC program expanded to 32 schools by the end of Fiscal Year 2012. In Fiscal Year 2013, the VSOC program expanded again to an additional 62 campuses, bringing the total number of VSOC sites to 94. Related Info: Are you a Veteran job seeker? Visit the Job Seeker Section to search jobs, translate your skills, and build a resume. Career Fairs In-person and online events where Veterans, Servicemembers, and their families can meet employers and learn about job opportunities. content: Hazardous Exposures: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Hazardous Exposures//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous Exposures Apply for Disability Benefits You may be eligible for disability compensation if you were exposed to certain chemical, physical, and environmental hazards during military service that resulted in disease or injury. Agent Orange The U.S. military sprayed millions of gallons of Agent Orange and other herbicides on trees and vegetation during the Vietnam War. Several decades later, concerns about the health effects from these chemicals continue. Asbestos Service activities and jobs that may have health consequences Birth Defects Contaminated Drinking Water at Camp Lejeune Chemicals in the camp's water from1953 to 1988 now pose health risks. Gulf War Illness The many diseases associated with serving in Southwest Asia Ionizing Radiation Exposure risks include nuclear testing, having been a POW in Japan, working with x-rays or at a reactor, and more. Mustard Gas Field or chamber testing, WWI battlefields, German bombing of Bari, Italy during WWII, and more. Project112/SHAD Chemical testing exposure --1962 to 1974 and survivor benefits. Radiogenic Risk Activities WWII-era service or imprisonment in Japan, nuclear weapons testing, gaseous diffusion plant assignment, and more. Specific Environmental Hazards Exposure problems in Iraq, Afghanistan, Dijibouti, Camp Lejune, NC, and Atsugi, Japan, from burn pits and particulate matter to chemically contaminated drinking water. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. content: Individual Unemployability: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Individual Unemployability//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsSpecial ClaimsIndividual Unemployability Apply for Disability Benefits If you are unable to maintain suitable gainful employment due to a service-connected disability, VA may designate you as individually unemployable and assign you a compensation level thatas the same as a 100% disabled Veteran. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You have at least one service-connected disability rated at least at 60%, or two or more service-connected disabilities, at least one of which has a 40% or more disability rating, and a combined rating of 70% or more. You are unable to maintain substantially gainful employment as a result of service-connected disabilities. Marginal employment, such as odd jobs, is not considered substantially gainful employment for VA purposes. In exceptional cases such as frequent hospitalization, this benefit may be granted at a lower disability rating. Who is covered You Available benefits Compensation Health care How it works When filing your claim, be sure to provide evidence or statements that your disability is preventing you from maintaining substantially gainful employment. Your work and education history will be reviewed. Example A Veteran has a service-connected heart condition that has been evaluated as 60% disabling. She has been able to work without difficulty until last year, when she began to experience chest pain with any exertion. Her physician recommended that she retire as soon as possible. She filed a claim for increased disability compensation. Evidence regarding the Veteranas work history and education were reviewed, and she was designated as individually unemployable due to her service-connected disability and entitled to compensation at the same rate as a 100% disabled Veteran. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.gov Search Close Search: Search: Content starts here. Veterans Employment Center For Employers Log in As an employer, you must sign in to search, view, and save Veteran resumes, or to publish / edit your Veteran hiring commitment. Sign in with LinkedIn Sign in with Google First time here? It's free and easy create an account -- simply log in with your LinkedIn or Google account below. On your first login, we'll ask for your company name and EIN. You can use all employer features as soon as you sign in, but we have to approve you (by confirming your company name and EIN are real) before you can view Veteran names or email addresses. This process usually takes less than a day. Related Info: Workplace Support Some ways to support Veterans and Sevicemembers in the workplace. On the Job Training Both on-the-job training (OJT) and apprenticeship programs are available for Veterans using their VA education benefits, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill(r) Resources for Employers On-the-job training information, fact sheets, guides, and additional resources for employers. We're designing in the open. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.gov GI Bill(r) Benefits Comparison Tool Learn about education programs and compare estimated benefits by school EXPLOREYOUR CAREER CareerScope COMPARESCHOOLS GI BillComparison Tool CHOOSEA SCHOOL Decision Guide APPLY FORGI BILL VONAPP SUCCEEDIN SCHOOL EducationalCounseling FINDEMPLOYMENT Employment Center Step 1: Tell Us About Yourself About You: Military Status: Veteran Active Duty National Guard / Reserves Spouse Child Is your spouse on active duty? Spouse Active Duty Spouse Not Active Duty Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? Post-9/11 GI Bill (Ch 33) Montgomery GI Bill (Ch 30) Select Reserve GI Bill (Ch 1606) REAP GI Bill (Ch 1607) Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E) Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) Cumulative Post 9-11 Active Duty Service: 36+ months: 100% (includes BASIC) 30 months: 90% (includes BASIC) 24 months: 80% (includes BASIC) 18 months: 70% (excludes BASIC) 12 months: 60% (excludes BASIC) 6 months: 50% (excludes BASIC) 90 days: 40% (excludes BASIC) Less than 90 days 0% (excludes BASIC) GYSGT Fry Scholarship: 100% Service-Connected Discharge: 100% Completed an enlistment of: 3 or more years 2 or more years Length of Longest Active Duty Tour: 2+ years of consecutive service: 80% 1+ year of consecutive service: 60% 90+ days of consecutive service: 40% To apply for VR&E benefits, please visit this site. Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Not Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Number of Dependents 0 Dependents 1 Dependent 2 Dependents 3 Dependents 4 Dependents 5 Dependents Military Status Post 9/11 GI Bill recipients serving on Active Duty (or transferee spouses of a servicemember on active duty) are not eligible to receive a monthly housing allowance. Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? You may be eligible for several types of VA education and training benefits depending on when and how long you served. There are several things to consider before you apply for a GI Bill program. One person may benefit more by using the Montgomery GI Bill while another may make an irrevocable election and use the Post-9/11 GI Bill instead. This tool allows you to compare the different programs and make an educated decision on which benefit best suits your needs. For more detailed information on eligibility requirements and general program benefits, please check out this page. Cumulative Post-9/11 Service The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides financial support for education and a housing allowance to qualifying individuals with at least 90 days of aggregate service after September 10, 2001, or individuals discharged with a service-connected disability after 30 days. You must have received an honorable discharge to be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill.For more detailed information Cumulative Post-9/11 Service, please check out this page. Completed an enlistment of (MGIB): The Montgomery GI Bill - Active Duty provides education benefits to Veterans and Servicemembers who have served at least two years of active duty. When using this tool, you will need to select the length of your original active duty enlistment obligation in order to get an estimate of your monthly benefit. The amount of time you served (2 year enlistment vs. 3+ year enlistment) will impact your monthly payment amount when using the Montgomery GI Bill. To learn more about MGIB please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/mgib_ad.asp Length of Longest Active Duty Tour (REAP) The REAP program pays benefits to eligible Reservists or Guard members who were called or ordered to active duty for at least 90 consecutive days in response to a war or national emergency declared by the President or Congress. REAP payment amounts are based on length of consecutive days of active duty service with rates increasing at one year and again at two years of consecutive service. To learn more about REAP please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/reap.asp. $(document).ready(function() { ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Military Status select show and hide ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#military-status').change(function() { showDependent('#military-status', 'spouse', '#spouse-active-duty-form', 100); }).change(); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // GI Bill benefit select ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#gi-bill-chapter').change(function() { var opt = $(this).val(); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '33', '#cumulative-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '30', '#enlistment-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '1607', '#consecutive-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#voc-rehab-warning', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#elig-for-post-gi-bill-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#number-of-dependents-form', 100); }).change(); $('.filter-item').change(function() { runEstimator(); }).change();});// Makes the modals work!$("a[rel*=leanModal]").leanModal(); Use the VA's GI Bill Comparison Tool to make the most of your GI Bill Benefit. Whether you want to apply your GI Bill benefits to college classes or an on-the-job training program, this tool will help you make the most of them. $ Tuition & Fees $ Housing $ Books What's Your Plan? Transitioning to civilian life takes preparation, research, planning, and the right tools. We're here to help you make the right decisions on where to use your hard earned benefits! Step 2: About Your School Will you be taking classes online? All No Both Enter a city, school or employer name: $(document).ready(function() { $('#institution-search').val(""); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Institution autocomplete ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#institution-search').autocomplete({ minLength : 3, source: "/gi-bill-comparison-tool/institutions/autocomplete.json", select: function(event, ui) { event.preventDefault(); $("#institution-search").val(ui.item.value); $('#input-section').submit(); }, }); $('#institution-search').keypress(function(e) { if ((e.keyCode == 13 || e.which == 13) && !$(this).val()) { e.preventDefault(); } }); $("#search-button").click(function(e) { if (!$('#institution-search').val()) { e.preventDefault(); } });}); Post 9/11 GI Bill Approved Programs You can use the Post-9/11 GI Bill at colleges, universities, trade schools, and for on-the-job training, apprenticeship, and flight schools. To see what programs are currently approved for VA benefits, go to our website. You can use the Post 9/11 GI Bill for tutorial assistance, licensing/certification tests (attorney license, cosmetology license, etc.) and national exams (SAT, LSAT, etc.). The Post 9/11 GI Bill Comparison Tool uses a list of schools offering approved programs from VA's database. The GI Bill Comparison Tool will update its list of approved programs quarterly. However, new information is added to the VA database every day. content: Principles of Excellence Program: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Principles of Excellence Program//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsCareer CounselingPrinciples of Excellence Program The Principles of Excellence program requires participating educational institutions to: Provide a personalized form to help you understand the total cost of your educational program, including: Costs covered by your benefits. Financial aid you may qualify for. Your estimated student-loan debt upon graduation. Other information to help you compare aid packages offered by different schools. Provide an educational plan with a completion timeline that shows how and when you can fulfill the requirements for graduation. Designate a point of contact to provide you with ongoing academic and financial advice (including access to disability counseling). Accommodate both long and short absences due to service obligations for active-duty Servicemembers and Reservists. Ensure accreditation of all new programs before enrolling students. Align their refund policies with those under Title IV, which governs the administration of federal student financial aid programs. End fraudulent and aggressive recruiting techniques and misrepresentations. Institutions that do not charge tuition and fees are not required to comply with the Principles of Excellence. This includes: Foreign schools High schools On-the-job training and apprenticeship programs Residency and internship programs Use the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool to maximize your educational benefits and learn which schools participate. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Predischarge//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPredischarge Predischarge It is to your benefit to start the process of filing a disability claim while you are on active duty in predischarge status. Processing times tend to be faster for claims submitted before separation than for those submitted after separation. If you are in predischarge status, you may file a claim for disability compensation up to 180 days prior to separation or retirement from active duty or release from full-time Reserve or National Guard periods of duty. If you are between 60 and 180 days from separation, you can begin the Benefit Delivery at Discharge (BDD) program. Between 1 and 59 days before separation, you can initiate the Quick Start Claim. See also Benefit Delivery at Discharge (BDD) program Quick Start program Overseas Intake Sites Disability Compensation Rates Other programs available to predischarge Servicemembers Standard Claim Original Claim Reopened Claim New Claim Secondary Claim Fully Developed Claim (FDC) Preservice Claim In-Service Claim Predischarge Claim Postservice Claim Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Standard Claim//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesStandard Claim If you file a standard claim, VA will gather evidence from public and private medical facilities so they can process your disability claim. VA will gather evidence from private medical facilities only with your authorization. Who can file a standard claim? You, your dependents and survivors Why use the standard claim process? If you want VA to assist you in gathering evidence to support your claim, you should file a standard claim. With your approval, VA will gather needed evidence, listed in your claim, including information not held by federal agencies. This may include medical records from: private medical providers private doctorsa offices state and local governments current or former employers Evidence Requirements Medical evidence of a current physical or mental disability, and Evidence of an event, injury, or disease while you were in service Note: A standard claim will generally take longer to process than a Fully Developed Claim. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Legacy Programs//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsLegacy Programs Before the Post-9/11 GI BillA(r), several smaller programs provided education benefits to Servicemembers and Veterans. Veteran Service Officers and the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool can help you pick the right program for your goals. Reserve Educational Assistance Program (REAP) Activated Reservists qualify for additional education benefits. National Call to Service An education benefit earned with a mix of military and civilian service. Veterans' Educational Assistance Program (VEAP) A government match program for educational assistance. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Kickoff//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]> Playbook Product Methodology Kickoff Step 2: Kickoff The kickoff meeting is conducted after completion of project definition and brings together the entire project team. It creates alignment and shared understanding of the projectas goals, scope, milestones, roles and responsibilities. It builds on the project definition phase by eliciting known business requirements, user needs and technical platform dependencies. Output Kickoff meeting i Draft Project Plan i Leads Project Team POC VA Business Owner VA Product Lead Participants VA kickoff attendees identified by VA Business Owner Project Team POC Design Team Engineering Team VA Business SMEs VA Technical SMEs (as needed) VA Stakeholder Engagement Ensure the right people attend the kickoff meeting given the agenda Work collaboratively with the vets.gov team to prepare for the kickoff Team Assemble entire team. (Invite subject matter experts, when relevant.) Review project goals, timeline and definitions. Adjust as needed. Develop sprint cycle plan Review known business requirements. Review known user needs Review known technical and platform dependencies Identify constraints and risks Back: Project Definition Next: Discovery Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. content: Licensing and Certification: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Licensing and Certification//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsTraining, Testing, or LicensingLicensing and Certification If you are a Veteran looking for employment in a field that requires a license or certification, you may be eligible for VA GI BillA(r) reimbursement for licensing or certification exams. Are you eligible for compensation? Yes, if: You are eligible for the GI BillA(r) You are taking an exam that costs less than $2,000 Who is covered You Available benefits Reimbursement under the GI BillA(r) How it works VA may reimburse you for tests necessary for you to become a licensed or certified mechanic, medical technician, attorney, therapist, website developer, computer network engineer, or other professional. After you submit proof of payment, VA will reimburse you. There is no limit to the number of tests you may take, or the number of times you take the same test. VA pays for tests even when you donat score high enough to achieve your license or certification. Find out how your GI BillA(r) entitlement will be charged for using a licensing and certification benefit. Fees associated with obtaining a license or certification are not reimbursable. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Preservice Claim//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsClaims ProcessClaim TypesPreservice Claim Claims Based on Preservice Disabilities If you entered the military with a known disability that became worse or was aggravated due to your service, you may be eligible for benefits. In these cases, disability compensation is calculated based on the level of aggravation. For example, if you had a condition that was 10% disabling when you entered the military and it worsened due to service to 20% disabling, then the level of aggravation would be 10%. content: Apply for Education Benefits: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Apply for Education Benefits//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Education BenefitsApply for Education Benefits Who Should Read This Servicemembers and Veterans seeking education and training opportunities How long does a decision take? The time it takes to process your claim depends on your regional office. There are four regional claims processing centers, and it varies region by region. You can use VAas interactive map to find out how quickly your regional office processes claims. What are the steps? Research Learn about schools offering VA-approved programs by using the GI BillA(r) Comparison Tool. Decide which school is best for you. Please note that it is not required, but it is an option, to apply to a chosen school prior to applying for benefits. Gather Your Documents The following documents will help VA process your claim: DD214 (Member 4), discharge or separation papers, for all periods of active-duty service, excluding active duty for training DD2384, Notice of Basic Eligibility (NOBE), which you can get through your Reserve unit Orders, if activated from the Guard or the Reserves Apply You have four options for filing your claim: Apply online using eBenefits. Go to a VA regional office and have a VA employee assist you. Work with your schoolas VA certifying official. This person is usually in the Registrar or Financial Aid office at the school of your choice. Call 888-GI Bill (888-442-4551) to have the application mailed to you. After you complete it, mail it to your VA regional claims processing office. VA Review You can track the status of your application on eBenefits. Please note: Content on this Web page is for informational purposes only.A It is not intended to provide legal advice or to be a comprehensive statement or analysis of applicable statutes, regulations, and case law governing this topic. Rather, itas a plain-language summary. If you are seeking claims assistance, your local VA regional office, a VA-recognized Veterans Service Organization, or a VA-accredited attorney or agent can help. Search for help near you. We're designing in the open. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.gov GI Bill(r) Benefits Comparison Tool Learn about education programs and compare estimated benefits by school EXPLOREYOUR CAREER CareerScope COMPARESCHOOLS GI BillComparison Tool CHOOSEA SCHOOL Decision Guide APPLY FORGI BILL VONAPP SUCCEEDIN SCHOOL EducationalCounseling FINDEMPLOYMENT Employment Center Step 1: Tell Us About Yourself About You: Military Status: Veteran Active Duty National Guard / Reserves Spouse Child Is your spouse on active duty? Spouse Active Duty Spouse Not Active Duty Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? Post-9/11 GI Bill (Ch 33) Montgomery GI Bill (Ch 30) Select Reserve GI Bill (Ch 1606) REAP GI Bill (Ch 1607) Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E) Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) Cumulative Post 9-11 Active Duty Service: 36+ months: 100% (includes BASIC) 30 months: 90% (includes BASIC) 24 months: 80% (includes BASIC) 18 months: 70% (excludes BASIC) 12 months: 60% (excludes BASIC) 6 months: 50% (excludes BASIC) 90 days: 40% (excludes BASIC) Less than 90 days 0% (excludes BASIC) GYSGT Fry Scholarship: 100% Service-Connected Discharge: 100% Completed an enlistment of: 3 or more years 2 or more years Length of Longest Active Duty Tour: 2+ years of consecutive service: 80% 1+ year of consecutive service: 60% 90+ days of consecutive service: 40% To apply for VR&E benefits, please visit this site. Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Not Eligilble for Post-9/11 Gi Bill Number of Dependents 0 Dependents 1 Dependent 2 Dependents 3 Dependents 4 Dependents 5 Dependents Military Status Post 9/11 GI Bill recipients serving on Active Duty (or transferee spouses of a servicemember on active duty) are not eligible to receive a monthly housing allowance. Which GI Bill benefit are you thinking of using? You may be eligible for several types of VA education and training benefits depending on when and how long you served. There are several things to consider before you apply for a GI Bill program. One person may benefit more by using the Montgomery GI Bill while another may make an irrevocable election and use the Post-9/11 GI Bill instead. This tool allows you to compare the different programs and make an educated decision on which benefit best suits your needs. For more detailed information on eligibility requirements and general program benefits, please check out this page. Cumulative Post-9/11 Service The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides financial support for education and a housing allowance to qualifying individuals with at least 90 days of aggregate service after September 10, 2001, or individuals discharged with a service-connected disability after 30 days. You must have received an honorable discharge to be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill.For more detailed information Cumulative Post-9/11 Service, please check out this page. Completed an enlistment of (MGIB): The Montgomery GI Bill - Active Duty provides education benefits to Veterans and Servicemembers who have served at least two years of active duty. When using this tool, you will need to select the length of your original active duty enlistment obligation in order to get an estimate of your monthly benefit. The amount of time you served (2 year enlistment vs. 3+ year enlistment) will impact your monthly payment amount when using the Montgomery GI Bill. To learn more about MGIB please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/mgib_ad.asp Length of Longest Active Duty Tour (REAP) The REAP program pays benefits to eligible Reservists or Guard members who were called or ordered to active duty for at least 90 consecutive days in response to a war or national emergency declared by the President or Congress. REAP payment amounts are based on length of consecutive days of active duty service with rates increasing at one year and again at two years of consecutive service. To learn more about REAP please visit http://www.benefits.va.gov/gibill/reap.asp. $(document).ready(function() { ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Military Status select show and hide ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#military-status').change(function() { showDependent('#military-status', 'spouse', '#spouse-active-duty-form', 100); }).change(); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // GI Bill benefit select ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#gi-bill-chapter').change(function() { var opt = $(this).val(); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '33', '#cumulative-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '30', '#enlistment-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '1607', '#consecutive-service-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#voc-rehab-warning', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#elig-for-post-gi-bill-form', 100); showDependent('#gi-bill-chapter', '31', '#number-of-dependents-form', 100); }).change(); $('.filter-item').change(function() { runEstimator(); }).change();});// Makes the modals work!$("a[rel*=leanModal]").leanModal(); Use the VA's GI Bill Comparison Tool to make the most of your GI Bill Benefit. Whether you want to apply your GI Bill benefits to college classes or an on-the-job training program, this tool will help you make the most of them. $ Tuition & Fees $ Housing $ Books What's Your Plan? Transitioning to civilian life takes preparation, research, planning, and the right tools. We're here to help you make the right decisions on where to use your hard earned benefits! Step 2: About Your School Will you be taking classes online? All No Both Enter a city, school or employer name: $(document).ready(function() { $('#institution-search').val(""); ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// // Institution autocomplete ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// $('#institution-search').autocomplete({ minLength : 3, source: "/gi-bill-comparison-tool/institutions/autocomplete.json", select: function(event, ui) { event.preventDefault(); $("#institution-search").val(ui.item.value); $('#input-section').submit(); }, }); $('#institution-search').keypress(function(e) { if ((e.keyCode == 13 || e.which == 13) && !$(this).val()) { e.preventDefault(); } }); $("#search-button").click(function(e) { if (!$('#institution-search').val()) { e.preventDefault(); } });}); Post 9/11 GI Bill Approved Programs You can use the Post-9/11 GI Bill at colleges, universities, trade schools, and for on-the-job training, apprenticeship, and flight schools. To see what programs are currently approved for VA benefits, go to our website. You can use the Post 9/11 GI Bill for tutorial assistance, licensing/certification tests (attorney license, cosmetology license, etc.) and national exams (SAT, LSAT, etc.). The Post 9/11 GI Bill Comparison Tool uses a list of schools offering approved programs from VA's database. The GI Bill Comparison Tool will update its list of approved programs quarterly. However, new information is added to the VA database every day. content: Agent Orange Registry Health Exam for Veterans: Vets.govnew WOW().init(); This site is a work in progress. If you don't find what you need, visit VA.gov. Vets.govSearchClose Search: Search: Agent Orange Registry Health Exam for Veterans//<![CDATA[ var usasearch_config = { siteHandle:"vets.gov_staging" }; var script = document.createElement("script"); script.type = "text/javascript"; script.src = "https://search.usa.gov/javascripts/remote.loader.js"; document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);//]]>Disability BenefitsConditionsHazardous ExposuresAgent OrangeAgent Orange Registry Health Exam for VeteransApply for Disability Benefits If you suspect you were exposed to Agent Orange or other herbicides during your military service, you can request a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam. Even if you donat have a known illness, the exam could alert you to health problems that may be related to herbicide exposure. Your participation also helps VA better understand and serve those affected by Agent Orangearelated health problems. Contact your local VA Environmental Health Coordinator if you are interested in getting an Agent Orange Registry health exam. Are you eligible for an Agent Orange Registry health exam? Yes, if you served in Vietnam between 1962 and 1975, regardless of length of time. Vietnam on smaller river patrol and swift boats that operated on the inland waterways of Vietnam (also known as aBrown Water Veteransa). Check VAas list of U.S. Navy and Coast Guard ships that operated in Vietnam. Korea in a unit in or near the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) anytime between April 1, 1968, and August 31, 1971. Thailand (U.S. Air Force Veterans) on Royal Thai Air Force (RTAF) bases near U-Tapao, Ubon, Nakhon Phanom, Udorn, Takhli, Korat, and Don Muang near the air base perimeter anytime between February 28, 1961, and May 7, 1975. Thailand (U.S. Army Veterans) as perimeter security personnel on RTAF bases in Thailand anytime between February 28, 1961, and May 7, 1975. Thailand (U.S. Army Veterans) on some small Army installations in Thailand anytime between February 28, 1961, and May 7, 1975. You must have been a member of a military police (MP) unit or assigned a military occupational specialty with duty placing you at or near the base perimeter. Other locations but were exposed to herbicides during a military operation or as a result of testing, transporting, or spraying herbicides for military purposes. Learn about herbicide tests and storage outside Vietnam. Who is covered You How it works Contact your VA Environmental Health Coordinator to make an appointment for your exam. This comprehensive health exam is free to eligible Veterans and includes: Your exposure history Your medical history A physical exam Medical tests that may be needed A VA health professional will discuss your results with you and will follow up with a letter detailing your results. Important points about the Agent Orange Registry health exam: It is not a disability compensation exam, nor is it required for other VA benefits. If you want to be considered for disability compensation, you must file a claim. You do not need to enroll in VAas health care system to receive a registry health exam. The exam is based on your recollection of service, not on your military records. The exam will not confirm exposure to Agent Orange. You can receive additional, free Registry exams if new problems develop. Veteransa family members are not eligible for an Agent Orange Registry health exam. Questions Contact your local VA Environmental Health Coordinator to make an appointment for your Agent Orange Registry health exam. Learn more about the Agent Orange Registry health exam. Find an Accredited Representative to help you.
